At low water at noon looked out a place on a hard beach where the vessel would not cut in with the intention of putting the vessel stove tomorrow mom gave crew liberty to go home nothing to do on board to day

Wind Southerly Got the Chromo on beach North of Steamboat wharf and grounded her but she went into the wind to far to find out what the damage is, only know it is trouble with her keel. have no idea yet what will have to be done with vessel. My wife came up from home to step on board while at Sullivan
notes: wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind North West quite a fresh breeze got foresail and jib on Chromo, and went back on flats again near the Old Salt works. where there will not be much pumping to do as the will set so deep in the mud At night it is decided to reship the load or as much as could in the Schr Ann, which is no above the Falls
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction and speed entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Southerly Schr Ann could not get over the Falls. and all we can do is to wait
notes: wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Easterly and rainy no vessel can get down over the falls, to take on board
notes: wind direction and weather cond entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Northwest and fresh breeze At noon the Schr Ann came along side from above the falls to take our load. Rigged up purchase in afternoon ready to work on monday
notes: wind direction and speed entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Westerly and fresh breeze cool but pleasant
notes: wind direction, speed and weather cond entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Southerly commenced discharging stone, putting them on board Schr Ann, to reship them In evening went to Negro Jubilee Concert comprised of singing
notes: wind direction and speed entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind North West in forenoon and South West in afternoon Work all day on stove discharging
Wind South South East Fresh breeze and looking like rain but did not rain hard enough to quit work
notes: wind direction, speed and weather cond entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Southerly Went home in forenoon to see about a certain note that becomes due to day Came back in the afternoon with my Daughter
notes: wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind South East in morning and Southerly in afternoon Made several calls in Sullivan with wife and daughter

Wind North West in forenoon and Southerly in afternoon Work all day forenoon taking out stone. and got the Ann loaded at noon And in the afternoon got the vessel underway and went to Mosleys beach to to let the vessel heel down for the purpose of calling a survey on her About 400 feet stone left on board more than the Ann could carry

Wind Southerly and when tide got down about Eleven oclock AM called survey on vessel survey consisted of the nun Master Corners Capt. Henry Stratton. After seeing one side of the vessel the survey decided the vessel must heel on other side before they passed their opinion in order to see both sides worked on the low water stoping the leaks temporaly the after end keel being started of
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Heeled vessel down on other side. and the survey decided it was best to go to Rockland and take the vessel out on Railway as her outer keel was all gone and her inner keel badly shattered, work on low water stoping leaks. Wind Southerly
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Calm all forenoon hauled vessel of beach in morning And in the afternoon wind breezed up Southerly at night went into Stave Island thick with fog Bound to Rockland as advised by survey

Wind North East and wet. foggy. Got underway in Stave Island at 2.30 am bound for Rockland to take vessel on Railway passed through Froy Island Thorough fare at noon. weather cleared up. Arrived in Rockland at 2 PM went to the Marine Railway Agent at the North End And finding the Railway was engaged. went to the Railway at the South End. agreed to take vessel out in morning
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction and weather cond entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Easterly and cloudy. Took Chromo on Railway in forenoon. and commenced work at noon taking the outer keel of and a part of the inner one
notes: wind direction and weather cond entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind East North East fresh breeze and rainy vessel layed on Railway at the South End at Rockland
notes: wind direction, speed and weather cond entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Southerly and thick with fog Work all day on Chromo on Railway

Wind South West Finished labor on the Chromo at Rockland at noon and put vessel in water Friyed up business with Railway Co and left Rockland at 3oclock PM for Sullivan and anchored at Froy Island at Sun set becalmed
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Northerly quite a fresh breeze got underway early at Froy Island for Sullivan. beat through Western way and up Frenchmans bay and anchored at Sullivan below the falls at 2 oclock in the afternoon
notes: wind direction, speed and weather cond entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind S.S.East. Got underway at 9 oclock AM and went over the falls to G.H. West wharf In afternoon sent for Stevedore to commence work tomorrow
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Southerly and showery. Work most all day making rail box, and rigging up derrick getting ready to work tomorrow hauling on board already 408 cubic feet that was left in more than the Schr Ann could take. when the Chromo load was reshiped after getting ashore in Falls
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction and weather cond entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Northerly in forenoon and Southerly in afternoon Work all day loading stone for G.H. West, mostly Random stone. Took in 634 cubic feet. Reed letter from my sister announcing the death of H.L. Norwood

Wind NorthWest with fresh breeze Hired team and went home accompanied by wife and daughter, and went to H.L. Norwoods funeral who was buried by the Masons At night went back to West Sullivan with my wife who intends to go to Philadelphia with me. leacing my daughter at home on th her grandmothers
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction and speed entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind North West in forenoon W.S.W in afternoon work all day loading stone. on board "Chromo"
Rainy all forenoon Wind Easterly. At 2 oclock in the afternoon rain ceased, commenced work loading. and at six oclock P.M. was loaded
notes: wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Calm in morning hauled from the wharf into the River. Got bills of laden. ready to sail but not wind enough to get over the falls. on Ebb tide wind breezed up Northerly
notes: wind direction and "breezed up" entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind North North West At 8 oclock AM got under way with pilot on board Went over the Falls at 9 AM. Passed Egg Rock at noon, and took the South West at 3PM of Bakers Island and busted foresail & Bent a new one at sunset, almost to Duck Island, Wind West by South. midnight wind West Southwest moderate

Calm almost all day. vessel did not got but little more than the slat of the sails and the current running westerly at dark sighted matinicus Rock at midnight matinicus Rock bore North by West and Monheigan bore N.W. by W.

Calm untill 3AM when the wind breezed up East Lat Noon 42.55 In the afternoon the sea began to make and the sky cloudy. at 5PM took in light sails and at 6 PM double reefed main sail and have to dare not run any further heavy sea and rain The lead kept going but no shoal water vessel laying head to the Southan and thick with fog
notes: unsure in bold, weather cond entered in am so do not specify

journal_entry: A continuation of the last four days. which is nothing but fog fog wind from E. to S. no seale. At 2 PM shore a fisherman laying by. said he was 4 miles South of Nausett in 19 fathoms water but by our line there was 25 fathoms at sunset fog lifted saw some part of Cape Cod thought it was between Chatham and Nausset. then thick. At 10 OM called watch Rufed mainsail went of shore fresh breeze
notes: unsure in bold, weather cond and wind speed entered in am so do not specify

journal_entry: Wind S.S.E. and at 3 AM wore ship headed Westerly at 8 AM moderate fog scaled saw Chatham at 10 AM called watch set all sail. apart of the day sunshine then rain. At 4 PM head the whistle on Pollock Rip. Light Ship also soon after the Whistling buoy on the broken part and tried to get on the shoals. At 5 PM fog lifted and saw the Lightship Tide turned ahead and anchored North from the buoy Wind S.W. partly clear
notes: unsure in bold, "sunshine" and "rain" entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: At one oclock in the morning got underway about 3 miles North poran the Pollock Rip Lujar Ship, Wind SouthWest and gradualy hauled West, and cleared up fine, beat over the Shoals, and anchored at Vineyard Haven at 5 oclock P.M. Wind very moderate at this time and tide turning ahead
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction and weather cond entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Very light Wind N.W. in morning got under way at Vineyard Haven and went out wind died out. Tide turned ahead. could not reach Vineyard Haven again. and anchored of East Chop at one PM. tide turned Westerly. wind W.S. West- Got anchor, and beat out by Tarpaulin Cove. but the wind blew very fresh and rough went back to Tarpaulin Cove and anchored, as did sixteen other vessels.
notes: wind speed entered in am so do not specify

journal_entry: Wind West South West and very fresh breeze, all day. Lay at anchor all day on board "Chromo"
Wind South South West commenced raining early in morning and rained hard. Lay at anchor all day in Tarpaulin Cove no light up to the fog for the day
notes: wind direction and speed entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind West South West fresh breeze and thick with fog, all the forenoon but in the afternoon the fog sealed but the tide was ahead and could not beat out by Gay Head
notes: wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind SouthWest with quite a fresh breeze Got underway at 4 A.M. wind increasing got as far as Point Judith. and could get no further as the wind was blowing very heavy and rough. Kept of and went into Dutch Island Harbor. as did all other vessels that did not go into New Port which was more than 100
wind_speed_am: fresh breeze, blowing very heavy, rough
notes: wind direction and speed entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Very moderate S.W. in morning. Got underway at Dutch Island Harbor and beat out. At 4 P.M. close into Block Island Wind South and overcast with little rain. bound out side of Long Island for Philadelphia. At 6.45 P.M. passed Montaul. wind increasing and hauling Easterly, and threatening at 9 P.M. took in both topsails, midnight blowing fresh and rough

This day begins with the wind South blowing fresh sea increasing and heavy rain. At 2 A.M. wind hauled a little Westerly and headed the vessel of at 7 am wind S.W. and thick with fog. kept vessel heading W. at noon wind moderate at 3 P.M. fog scaled and saw. Highland of Neversink at 6 P.M. Wind West and very moderate. Jacked ship headed S.S.West. This day ends calm and we South of Neversink

Very moderate all day Wind Northerly, at Noon Barnegat bore W.S.W. distant 10 miles in afternoon a dead air Southerly and at sunset Barnegat bore West and at midnight it bore the same there not being any wind since sunset
notes: unsure in bold, wind entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: This day begins calm and at 4 AM wind breezed up Northerly and hauled around Easterly. At noon Lat. 39.08, and at 4PM. passed inside of fine fathom bank Light-Ship, and at dark passed between the Capes of Delaware strong head tide and at midnight most up to the Brandy wine raining hard and beginning to blow fresh very dark so ends these 24 hours
Wind South East and blowing very very fresh. at one AM anchored near the Brandywine and at 4 AM got underway. rain ceased and at 7 P.M. anchored at the mouth of the Schuylkill
notes: weather cond entered in am so do not specify

journal_entry: Wind South West Took a tug boat at day light and towed up the Schuylkill River but no place to discharge stone have to wait for other vessels
notes: wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: No chance to discharge stone wait all day for another vessel Wind southerly Got coal under at Wilson Stearley to Co 127 Walnut St to go at Port Richmond Pier 16 to load with coal for Saco Me freight $1.45 per ton towed & discharged
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Calm all day got into the berth to discharge at 4 oclock PM and commenced work
Wind Southerly Work untill 5 P.M. onloading stone when a great thunder shower came up and rained in torrents men quit work
weather_condition_pm: great thunder storm, rained in torrents
notes: wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind South West finished onloading at 10 AM. Settled up for fright. Took tug boat and towed to Port Richmond to load with coal Got in the dock at 2 P.M. and at 4 PM commenced loading Got about 100 tons in Took Horse cars and went to my brokers mess Wilson Stearly & Co 127 Walnut St. Got check for J HWest $100. No 1761 check for Baker & Smith #26. No 1759 A.P. Fross 1760 $10.00
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Chromo loaded at 9 AM. Sent G.H.West check for $100. Baker & Smith check $26 at 9.30 took tug boat and at noon anchored at Chester Wind Southerly and tide ahead. At 5 oclock PM the tide turned Ebb, got anchor and beat down to New Castle anchored at 8.30 P.M.

Got underway at 4 AM with the winds S.S.W. and at 11 A.M. took the wind South East and the tide ahead abreast of the Ship John Shoal and anchored. In afternoon when tide turned got under way and at 9 PM anchored between Cross Ledge light and 14 foot bank Light Ship. at 11.30 P.M. took a heavy squall with rain Wind W.S.W. So Ends these 24 hours

Wind South West fresh Got underway at 4 AM and passed out the Delaware vetween the Capes at 8AM, In the afternoon wind South and heavy rain took in light sails, and at 4 PM about 24 miles from 5 fathom bank light ship and put over the log. At 8 PM, Wind hauled W.N.W., and at 9.30 Barnegat bore W.N.W. Wind fresh and clear. Midnight Barnegat-bore WSW 15 miles set light-sails

Wind West very early and gradually hauled SouthWest. at 9 AM abrest of Fire Island & at noon abrest of Shinnecock Light-house at 4 PM passed by Montauk. at 6 PM passed Block Island. at 11.45 oclock mid night just passed Tarpaulin Cove. Wind blowing fresh SouthWest

Wind SouthWest passed by Vineyard Haven at 12.30 AM Cross Rip at 2 AM and off the Shoals at 5 AM. passed Cape Cod Light-house at 9.30 AM. At 4 oclock in the afternoon took a squall from the North West about the time expected to see Boon Island. Then the wind died out. rain and fog came in and could make nothing. At midnight fog began to lift Wind W

Wind West at 1230 AM saw several lights and made Cape Elizabeth. Wood Island, and Boon Island lights. Wind hauled North. anchored at Wood Island at 6 A.M. wind blowing very heavy In the afternoon towed to Saco

Wind South East commenced discharging coal at Saco Me freight $145 towed and discharged Senf check to A Richards & Co for $24.41 - No 335 Sent check to Mefsrs Perley Russell & for $23.60 No 336 Both checks from John Iuimby on Saco National bank
notes: unsure in bold, wind direction entered in am aso do not specify

journal_entry: Wind Southerly Finished onloading at 9AM and towed out River from Saco at 10 AM, bound for Sullivan Me. At 6 oclock P.M. passed Monhegan. Wind hauled Easterly kept of fore White Head Wind moderate. Passed Ash Island in the mussle ridges at midnight. So ends these 24 hours
notes: wind direction entered in am as do not specify

journal_entry: Wind South Easterly and moderate At 5 oclock A.M. passed through Deer Isle thorough fare moderate. Went over Bass Harbor brar at noon. passed Bunkers Eastern ledge at 2 PM and at three oclock PM wind died out towed boad and towed into Outer Creek to keep vessel from drifting ashore
notes: wind direction entered in am as do not specify.

journal_entry: Wind Southerly and thick with fog, moderate. At 2 oclock P.M Wind breezed up fog lifted got underway at Otter Creek and went to Sullivan Took tug boat and towed over the Falls and anchored in the River
Wind South South East Commenced raining at 10 AM and rained hard most of the remainder of the day. At 6 pm hired team and went home with my wife

Wind South Easterly heavy rain all the forenoon settled acct Dutch Baker & Smith and N. Hammond In the afternoon cleared up. and at 6 oclock P.M. left home to go back to West Sullivan to go on board of the Chromo got on board just after dark at that time heavy rain with thunder and lightning

Wind South by East and thick with fog Got Chromo under way and went to Franklin to load stone. Expect to load for J H West At night agreed to load for H West for New York Did not agree with  J. H. West as he was away to New York but agreed with his Aigt. Expect $24 per m as that is what I have been offered by J.P.G.
Wind Southerly and some fog. Commenced loading with stone The stone brought along side in scows and put on board Crew stow them at night had 6200 expect eh vessel is about half loaded
Wind Southerly until 4 PM when a little squall came up North East Went to Sullivan Custom Hause Got a new set of papers including Enrolment Got two scow loads of paving
Calm in forenoon and very hot Lying at Franklin Schr Chromo

Calm. Four scow loads of paving came of at one oclock in the morning with over 4000 blocks had them all on board at 7 AM. At 9 AM took tug boat and towed down to the anchorage and at 4 PM took the boat and towed out over the Falls Wind S.S.W moderate anchored below the Falls whole amount of paving blocks on board 13.100 freight $13.50

Wind South Easterly and thick with fog Got underway and worked down the bay at Sunset of the Southern end of Turtle Island and bound into Winter Harbor after a man. a little after dark took a light-air of wind N and at 11 oclock in the evening anchored abrest of Mark Island in the South took the boat and went home arrived at midnight So ends these 24 hours
Wind Southerly went all day after a man, went to Birch Harbor but got one, did not get out in vessel

Wind South and thick with fog all day Could not get out wind very moderate Got Thomas Joy to agreee to to New York with me. In evening went to a traveling exhibition at the Hall Winter Harbor accompanied by wife and daughter

Wind South West by South moderate all the forenoon. But in the afternoon wind breezed up but the fog very thick. Got underway at Winter Harbor and beat out. at dark saw Duck Islands being near in shore at 11 PM. tacked ship close in to Mt Desert Rock. When the fog set in again and did not lift during the remainder of these 24 hours

Wind South West by West and thick with fog. & At 6 am wind hauled Northerly and cleared up and at 9 AM Matinicus Rock bore N.w. 10 miles. Wind moderate all day. and in the afternoon nearly calm. At 6 PM light air Southerly at 10 PM wind breezed up North fresh. So ends these 24 hours

Wind North quite fresh at 8 AM. Saw High land of Cape Cod then wind moderated Was abrest of the Old Cape at noon at 3 PM light air Southerly at 8 PM was abrest of Nauset and at midnight abrest of Chatham Still trying to cook on the Shoal. So ends these 24 hours

Wind South West. at 2 oclock AM anchored South of Chatham. At 7 AM got underway and went on the Shoals but the wind blew a gale hauled down mainsail and went back and anchored between Chatham & Monomoy wind blowing a gale at dark sharp lightning Wind W. at 9 PM. rain at 10 PM calm at midnight clear weather Wind S.W. So ends these 24 hours
Wind West moderate got underway at 7 AM and went on Shoals beat ver and anchored at Vineyard Haven at 1130 P.M.

Wind South West and fresh. Laid at anchor all day at Vineyard Haven as did all the rest of the fleet in the afternoon I went ashore at Cottage City it being a Celebration day but nothing of importance was going on
Wind South West. Got underway When the tide turned at noon to run W. beat by Tarpaulin Cove and anchored at Menemsha Bite at 5 oclock P.M. Menemsha Bite is about 2 miles East from Gay Head

Wind South West and thick with fog. At noon cleared up and got underway on turn of the ride passed Viney and Somet Light Ship at 3.30 P.M. and at midnight between Brentons Reef Light Ship and Point Judith So ends these 24 hours

Wind South West & moderate at 4 AM abrest of Point Judith at noon abrest of Watch Hill. Took the tide ahead in the Race. Wind breezed and stemed through into Long Island Sound. At dark abrest of Plum Island Light at midnight abrest of Falkner Island Island be calmed so ends these 24 hours
location: Point Judith, Watch Hill, Long Island Sound, Falkner Island

journal_entry: Calm until 8 oclock in the morning when took wind North. passed by Stratford Shoal middle ground at 10 AM At noon Wind N.N.E. and rainy. Passed Eatons Neck. Passed Execution Rocks at 3 P.M. and anchored at Rickens Island at 4.15 raining hard wind. N.E.
location: Stratford Shoal, Eatons Neck, Execution Rocks, Rickens Island

journal_entry: Wind North East overcast. At 5 oclock A.M. towed through Hell Gate anchored  at Red Hook in the afternoon Towed Chromo up North River to 12th Street to discharge stone. but got no berth and lay out side of anchor vessel to wait.
location: Hell Gate, Red Hool, North River

journal_entry: Wind Northerly and Westerly No berth to discharge stone. Went to fed Tuuge to Co 47 water Street and got and order for Iron to load at Haboken for South New Mauket N.H. above Portsmouth freight $1.75 per ton with the accostumed towage
Wind SouthWest laying at a pier near big Twelvth street mailing for a chance to discharge stone on board Chromo. North River
Wind  SouthWest as there was no chance to discharge to day. I have been engaged all day in painting vessel at night heavy thunder and rain squall from the Southward
Wind SouthWest Commenced in the morning to dicharge Chromo at 7 PM. a heavy thunder and rain squall from the North

Wind moderate Southerly Finished discharging stone, at noon had on board 12921 blocks. At 4 P.M. took tug and went to Haboken to load pig Iron for South New market N.H. Freight &1.45 per ton and towed at So New Market Did not commence work loading today
Calm all forenoon and very hot. In the afternoon wind S.S.E. and at night heavy rain. staid on board Chromo all day. at the wharf in Haboken N.J.

Wind Westerly Commenced loading pig Iron in the morning and at night the Chromo was loaded Shiped a man and got on board my ship stones. Got bills of lading and every thing ready to sail Chromo hood on board 190 tons Iron at $1.75 per ton the cost to load by hiring it all done was 12 cts per ton

Calm in morning at 4 AM took tug boat and towed through the Gates wind breezed up S passed Eatons Neck at 4 PM Passed Hortons Point at 6.30 PM Passed Race Rock at 10 P.M. very cloudy and looking very much like a stone, but am in hope to make Point Judith at midnight saw Point Judith light and run for Vineyard Sound Light vessel
location: Eatons Neck, Hortons Point, Race Rock, Point Judith, Vineyard Sound Light

journal_entry: Wind South by West and fresh breeze. At 4 am passed Vineyard Sound Light ship partialy foggy and rainy. At 6 a.m. passed Vineyard Haven an at noon went of the Shoals. when it closed in with fog, but at 2 P.M. fog lifted but very moderate at dark Cape Cod Light bore W.N.W distant 4 miles when took the wind N.N.W and moderate at midnight Cape Cod bore S.W so ends these 24 hours

Wind N.N.W. and tacked stood to the Westward. and as we stood into Wellfleet Bay the wind North and as we neared Plymouth the wind hauled Easterly. kept vessel by the wind and when near Minots Rock the wind East and could just head for Thatchers Island but the wind kept hauling out. Southerly thence Westerly of at 10 PM abrest of Thatchers Island wind N.N.W same at midnight

Wind N.N.W untill noon when it died out and the Isle of Shoals bore North 2 miles dist but in the afternoon the wind breezed up moderate Southerly, and anchored at New Castle N.H. 5 P.M. Went ashore and telephoned to South New Market that the Chromo is here waiting to be towed up
Wind variable Commenced discharging Chromo in morning of Iron at night it was about two thirds out

Wind Westerly. Finished discharging vessel at noon, and settled with Consignees and in the afternoon the tug boat tool vessel down the River as far as the branch that goes to Dover. it being just through the third bridge from So New Market. Where we anchored for the night. There are four bridges to go through to go to South New Market there of them above Portsmouth

Calm in morning Tug took hold of vessel at 7 A.M. and towed down by Portsmouth and to Sea past Whales Back Took wind South Easterly and it hauled South Westerly and run for Matinicus Rock passed Boon Island at noon. At dark Lighted Monhegan at midnight wind Northerly and hauling Easterly monhegan at this time bore North. So ends these 24 hours
location: Portsmouth, Matinicus Rock, Boon Island, Monhegan

journal_entry: Wind Northerly and hauling Easterly. At 4 AM Matinicus Rock bore North about 5 miles distant. Wind went around Easterly & Southerly at dark Isleauhovet bore N.W. In evening light air Westerly. midnight abrest of Duck Island nearly becalmed

very light air South at sunrise abrest of Egg Rock bound to Sullivan and anchored at Sullivan at 830 A.M. Then went to Franklin by land and agreed to load for J P Gordon for Newark N.J. went back to Sullivan on board Chromo Weighed anchore took Pilot. Went to Franklin with the vessel
Wind South overcast and fresh breeze. Left the Chromo at noon to go ashore to get a team for home. Went to West Sullivan in boat and got a team at one P.M. and arrived home at 5 P.M. raining hard
Wind South Easterly and rainy most all day. Went to meeting in the afternoon at the Hall

Wind Southerly and in forenoon thick with fog. Was about home all day. agreed with Chas Straw to get the hay. let the Workshop to Mr. Staples for $1. per mouth for a tin shop paid the taxes fo the year. Settled accts with Capt N. Hammond
Wind NorthWest in forenoon and SouthWest in the afternoon. Left home at 9 AM with team for Franklin got on board at 2 P.M.
Wind Westerly staid on board all day with the promise of some stone but got none
Wind Southerly and thick with fog got on board seen load of paving block of 900
Wind Southerly took on board enough stone to make 7.400
Wind South and a very fresh breeze work all day loading took on board enough stone to make 13000 and called it a load. got bills of loading lying at Franklin all ready to sail

Wind W.S.West. got underway in morning and went down to the anchorage at West Sullivan. at 2.30 P.M. got tug boat and went over the Falls. and went to Sea. bound to New York at midnight Mt. Desert Rock light bore South West about 4 miles dist so ends these 24 hours
location: West Sullivan, New York, Desert Rock

journal_entry: Wind West. at 5 AM Mt Desert Rock bore N.N.E dist 8 miles Vessel heading South Westerly. Wind fresh. At 2 PM tacked ship headed NorthWest at 9 P.M. tacked ship and headed South West wind hauling more Northerly. midnight wind West North West 7 knot breeze. so ends these 24 hours

Wind West NorthWest at 11 oclock A.M. sighted Cape Cod on starboard bow. wind moderated. at 2 PM wind Southerly. abrest of Nausett at 6 PM where the wind hauled westerly at midnight Chatham Lights bore W.N.W. very moderate so ends these 24 hours

very moderate wind from SouthWest to North West. Went on the Shoals passed the Pollock Rip Light Ship at 2.30 AM. at 9 AM anchored at the Cross Rip tide turning East and calm. At 2 PM got anchor wind SouthWest. and at the turning of the tide at 9 PM anchored at Vineyard Haven. Calm.
location: Pollock Rip, Shoals, Cross Rip, Vineyard Haven

journal_entry: Calm or nearly so all day Got underway at Vineyard Haven at 6 AM and drifted with the tide by Tarpaulin Cove and when the flood tide made drifted back to the Eastward of Tarpaulin Cove. And on the Ebb tide at night to the Westward and was abrest of Gay Head at dark. At midnight Vineyard Sound Light Ship bore North abrest 2 miles distant. Wind breezing up N.E. and clear
location: Vineyard Haven, Tarpaulin Cove, Gay Head, Vineyard Sound

journal_entry: Wind from N.E. to E. at 6 am passed Block Island. and at 10.40 Went through the Race into Long Island Sound at dark passed Falkners Island and at midnight abrest of the middle ground between Stratford and Old Field. So ends these 24 hours
location: Block Island, Long Island, Falkners Island, Stratfor, Old Field

journal_entry: Wind North East anchored at Rickers Island at 8 AM. and at 2 oclock P.M. took tug boat towed through the gates, and sailed to Port Johnson, near Staten Island bound to Newark. but to late in the tide to get up the River and anchored
location: Rickers Island, Port Johnson, Staten Island, Newark

journal_entry: Wind SouthWest vessel lying at Port Johnson. Took the cars and went to Newark and went on board Schr Laurel and Annie E. Rickerson both Stone load and from Franklin, and found out my Consignees did not want the stone

Wind West South West "Chromo" at Port Johnson took cars and went to Jersey City to see Consignees finding they were at Newark took the train for that place and found them. They say the did not contract for the stone and do not want them. Therefore I consider it useless to tow to Newark and intend letting the vessel lay where she is untill further orders

Wind North West. Took cars and went to Jersey City at the Consignees Office and found the stone had been resold to N.Y. and that this vessel was not to go to Newark at all. Took cars and went back to Port Johnson. Got tug boat and towed to the foot of Bethune It near West 12th street N.Y. North River. It being the place where I am going to discharge
Wind North Easterly Chromo lying along side of wharf waiting for Brig Edith to discharge. there being room for only one at a time to discharge stone at the foot of Bethune St
Wind Easterly all day and rainy Nothing done towards discharging stone, as it is to wet
Wind North West and pleasant. Lying outside of the Brig "Edith" waiting for her to discharge stone

Wind Westerly and pleasant. The Brig Edith finished discharging at 11 AM and the "Chromo" took her place. Work all the afternoon discharging Chromo At night heavy thunder Shower Chastered "Chromo" to go to Habaken and load with from for South New market N.H. freight $1.60 per ton
Wind from West to South and rain squalls. Chromo lying at the wharf foot of Bethune St.
Finished loading Iron at 4 oclock PM Settled all my business in N.Y. got bills of Saden Shiped one mand and got all ready to sail Wind Southerly

Wind South South West at 6 oclock AM took tug boat and towed through Hell gate bound to South New market. Passed Execution Rock at 12 . Passed Eatons Neck at 3 PM Passed middle ground 4.30 PM Passed out the Race at midnight. stimming a strong current and the wind quite moderate. and a little rainy. So ends these 24 hours
location: Execution Rock, Hell Gate, Eatons Neck

journal_entry: Very moderate up to this hour 8 AM wind first on one side the on the other Point Judith bearing North from 8 am untill 12 pm dead clam but in the afternoon wind breezed up W.S.W. Passed Gay Head at 6.30 P.M. Wind hauled Northerly and moderated. and at midnight was between Tarpaulin Cove and Vineyard Haven Wind breezing
location: Point Judith, Gay Head, Tarpaulin Cove, Vineyard Haven

journal_entry: Wind North. took the tide ahead of the Handkerchief and win of the Shoals at 8 AM at noon calm at night took wind Westerly and passed Cape Cod Light at 11.30 P.M. Good weather & smooth
Wind Westerly. Passed Isles of Shoals 11.30 AM When took the wind N.N.W. anchored at New Castle NH at 2 P.M. bound to South New market N.H.
location: Isles of Shoals, New Castle, Newmarket

journal_entry: Went from West to South West. Got the tug boat and towed as far as Portsmouth Bridge, and laid along side of the Pier at the Bridge

Took tug boat. at Portsmouth bridge, and towed as far as the third bridge bound to So. New Market. Wind Easterly while getting through the bridge the hawser caught around a mans leg on board the tug boat and took his leg off. Tug boat then cast the Chromo of at the pier and carried the man and carried the man back to Portsmouth for medical aid
Wind N.N.E in morning and fresh breeze Tug boat came and towed Chromo to So New Market arriving at 11.30 AM and in the afternoon commenced discharging load of Iron Got out about 45 tons

very moderate Southerly, Finished discharging Chromo at 5 oclock P.M. Telephoned to Dover to Agt of tug boat that the Chromo was discharged ready to tow down Settled for freight with Swampsent machine Go ready to sail
Wind Easterly. Towed down river below Portsmouth and anchored. at 5 P.M. no chance to get out bound East.

An air of wind N.W. got underway at day light. and drifted out with the tide. then calm. At noon took a very light air Easterly passed by Boon Island at 6.30 in the afternoon, and at midnight Cape Porpoise light bore North about 6 miles distant wind very moderate so ends these 24 hours

At one oclock AM an air of wind from the North then calm at noon the wind began to breeze up Southerly. and at 4 oclock P.M. Seguin bore North and at 8.30 Matinicus Rock light bore North. At midnight saw Mt Desert Rock Light not far distant So ends these 24 hours

Wind South West at one oclock AM passed Mt Desert Rock light close to wind fresh. At 3 AM hove vessel to for day light weather thick and rainy. At 4.30 keped of and run for Egg Rock. fog sealed and run up the Bay for Sullivan anchored below the Falls at 6.30 AM and and at 8 am wind N.N.W blowing gale. & could not tow over falls took steamer went home
location: Mt Desert Rock, Egg Rock, Sullivan

journal_entry: Wind Southerly left home in morning and walked to South Gouldsboro to take the Steamer Rockland, for Sullivan. It being the way I came home yesterday. Got on board Chromo about noon. She towed over the falls this morning before I got to Sullivan Took vessels boat in the afternoon and went to Franklin to see about getting aloud for Chromo for N.Y. Chromo lying at Hopewell what W. Sullivan
Wind Westerly Riggers came at noon and worked in the afternoon on Chromo rigging rigger consisted of two men
Wind SouthWest Rigger worked untill noon and went home to Ellsworth and I took the Steam boat at Sullivan and went to Bar Harbor then took the Little Butter Cup and went home
Wind Southerly untill noon and came of West NorthWest Staid at home
Wind very moderate North West. Went to South Gouldsboro with my wife and took Str Rockland and went to Sullivan via Bar Harbor the took team and went up to the Chromo Lying at Blaisdells wharf
Wind Southerly Thick with fog in morning did nothing toward loading waiting for the Annie E. Rickerson to load. Bought 1/16 of Schr Chromo of Alford H Ford for the sum of $175.00 paid all cash
Wind Southerly. and thick with fog in the morning. Got 1300 paving the Annie E. Rickerson now being loaded hope to get loaded soon.
Calm in morning and thick with fog. Got two thousand paving blocks
Calm all forenoon Got 2000 blocks and the deckload along side
Wind Southerly Got 3000 paving feet hatches on and caulked them
Wind Southerly and thick with fog out side
Wind Southerly and drizzling rain all day Got the deckload of Strars on also 500 paving on deck to trim the vessel. At night wind North fresh but kept on raining In the evening North Easterly

Wind NorthWest The vessel being loaded got Bill of Laden at noon towed out over the falls and went to Bar Harbor to fill water and get a man of can after filling water and failing to get a man. Got under way at dark and went to Winter Harbor after one anchored at half frost tere in evening wind very moderate

Wind North West in morning hunted untill noon for a man to go a trip to New Bedford & got one. then wind South West, at 1 P.M. got underway at Winter Harbor and went out. At dark wind Westerly. and at 10 PM passed Mt Desert Rock Light midnight wind West North West So ends these 24 hours
location: New Bedford, Winter Harbor, Mt Desert Rock

journal_entry: Wind from W.N.W. to North West At 8 A.M. wind N.N.W and partly cloudy. noon obs alt of sum Correction add trul alt sub from zenith dis sums dec add Latitude Wind quite moderate

Wind Northerly and overcast. At 4 oclock in the morning sighted Cape Cod bearing West. Wind going to the Eastward. at 9 AM close into Nauset Wind East and blowing fresh Stemed the ride over the shoals. and at 4 oclock P.M. anchored in Vineryard Haven. bound to New Bedford Wind blowing to heavy to get there
location: Cape Cod, Nauset, Vineyard Haven, New Bedford

journal_entry: Wind North East. Got underway at Vineyard Haven in the morning. Could not fetch through Luicks Hole as the tide was a head and went out the Vineyard Sound and beat up Buzzards Bay and Anchored at 4 oclock in the afternoon in New Bedford
location: Vineyard Haven, Vineyard Sound, Buzzards Bay, New Bedford

journal_entry: Wind Southerly Lying in New Bedford with spars deck Schrooner Chromo
Wind South Easterly took deck load of afternoon and evening rainy
Wind W by South wind blowing a gale. could not get the spars ashore untill afternoon and no chance to go out

Wind West North West Got underway in New Bedford at day light and went out bound to N.Y. At sunset half way between Point Judith and Block Island. Wind moderate Westerly. Wid night not but little past Block Island. So ends these 24 hours.
location: New Bedford, New York, Point Judith, Block Island

journal_entry: Wind West South West. and blowing heavy passed in through the Race at 7 am. went over to Niantic and anchore during the Ebb tide. Got under again at 3 P.M. wind blowing very hard could not get along. brested flying jib. keped of and went back to New London anchored at 6 P.M.

Wind West SouthWest, fresh breeze in the forenoon. did not go out untill 4 P.M. when the tide commenced to run blood. at 7.50 P.M. rain squalls and wind hauled Northerly good breeze at 10 PM Passed Falkners Island raining hard At midnight abt six miles the middle ground between Stratford and Old Field so ends these 24 hours
rain untill 4 AM wind North Easterly. Passed execution Rocks at 7 am. and at 8 AM took tug boat to tow through Hell gates. and anchored of Red Hook
Wind South West. and pleasant. Took dimmer on board the Brig Marina with Capt David Moore and Capt Chas Johns

Wind Northerly and pleasant. The canal boat lying in side discharged to day Chromo begins tomorrow morning Got an order to go to Perth Amboy yo load with Pig Iron for Boston freight $1.35 and bridge money
Wind Northerly Chromo commenced to discharge but did not get her load all out at night as those were only there three teams to haul them away and the wharf being poor dare not pile them on

Wind NorthWest finish discharging at 8 in the morning at 10 A.M. took tug boat and towed as far as Governors Island bound to Penith Amboy. Put sail on vessel and went to Penith Amboy anchored at 9 P.M. of the wharves

Wind North in morning got anchore docked vessel under sail. Wind hauled Easterly then Southerly. Commenced to load at 11 oclock in forenoon In the afternoon went to N.Y. City by steam And at 4 P.M. raining hard. Staid all night on board the Brig Marema with Capt David Moore
Wind NorthWest in morning and pleasant. In the afternoon wind Southerly Went back on board the Chromo at Penith Amboy arriving at dark
Wind Easterly did not get loaded as expected. but no chance to go if I was ready

Calm all day Got underway in the morning at City Island, and when it came dark was not down to Execution Rocks Then took the wind to the Eastward. and beat passed Great Capt Island Clouding up and commencing to rain at midnight
Wind East North East and thick rainy At 2 oclock in the morning turned the vessel around and ran back for City Island and anchored at 4 in the morning Thick and rainy all day wind Easterly
Wind Easterly and thick with fog and rainy all day Lay at City Island midnight wind South West but thick

Wind South South West. Got underway at City Island at 6 A.M. thick and overcast at 1230 PM passed Old Field point at 3.30 passed Falkners Island at 6PM becalmed and heavy rain. at 7 P.M. wind N.N.W Passed out the race at 9 P.M. Midnight abrest of Point Judith wind the wind North and fresh so ends these 24 hours
location: City Island, Falkners Island, Point Judith

journal_entry: Wind hauled to the N.N.E at 2 AM took in both top suils passed the Viney and sound Light Ship at 3 am made to tack to get through Vineyard Sound. and run for Edgartown anchored at 7.30 a.m. It being no use to try to get over the Shoals and around Cape Cod
Wind North North East Lay at anchor at Edgartown

Wind North East Chromo lying all day at Edgartown No chance to get East. Took the yawl boat went into Cape Poge Pound to hunt for the bodies of Capt A L Mitchel and a boy who were drowned yesterday from the Schr AL mitchel while gunning in the pong Capt AL mitchel body was found. He was a native of Milbridge. The boy was not found
Wind North East. and at night South East. The tide being ahead did not go out of Edgartown

Wind South. Went out of Edgartown at 2.30 in the morn Passed the Cross Rip at Sunrise. passed Nauset at 1230 PM Cape Cod Light house at 2.45 minutes Rock 8.30 P.M. and Boston Light at 10 PM Anchored above Long Island at 11 P.M. Anchored down here for the reason there is a better chance to get underway than there is above as we are bound to Chelsea
location: Edgartown, Cross Rip, Nauset, Cape Cod Light, Boston Light, Long Island

journal_entry: Wind Southerly Got Chromo under way in Boston lower Harbor. and went to Chelsea undeer sail to the Magel furnace Co. with a load of Iron Drizzling rain In afternoon commenced discharging Cargo
Wind Northerly Went on board the Navereno. Capt. Ira Fross and Staped the afternoon and evening
Wind Easterly. Finished discharging Iron and collected freight money
Wind North Easterly hauled down through the bridge from Chelsea and anchored on the flats
Wind E.N.E. very fresh breeze with rain. lay all day at anchor in Boston
Wind Easterly fresh breeze no kind of a chance to get East
Wind Easterly and showery lay at anchor in Boston bowed East
Wind Easterly and in the afternoon met drizzling rain laid all day at anchor in Boston

Wind Northerly in the morning Got underway in Boston and went out Got past the Gaus and the wind died out. layed becalm a long time when the wind breezed up very moderate Easterly went back and anchored West from Long Island in Boston lower Harbor
Wind S.S. East. Got underway at day light in Boston and went out. wind blowing fresh and thick with rain Went into Salem at 8 oclock A.M.
At daylight wind came of from the West, and blew a perfect gale. Lay at anchor all day in Salem
Wind NorthWest. lay at the wharf in Gandner loading lumber

Wind Northerly Finished loading Chromo with lumber at noon. had on board by the survey here, a very little over 100 feet long lumber and 185 laths, and by reckoning 5 laths to one long lumber as they do here. I have on board equal to a little more than 137 feet At 4 P.M. Tug boat towed Chromo as far down the River of Port Richmond and anchored for the night wind then S.W.
Wind S.S. West . Took tug boat in the morning and towed as far down the River as Bath. and there  the boat left us & we anchored
Calm all day. Took tug boat at Bath to tow down River. The boat parted over hauser before starting the vessel ahead. Then we anchored the tow went down River and left us at Bath
Wind SouthWest. no boat came near to low us down River and we lay at anchor all day at Bath

Wind north Got under way at Bath at 7 A.M. There not being any tow boat around went down River under sail Passed Pond Island Light house at 9 AM Abrest of Thatches Island at 6.30 P.M. and then run for Cape Cod passed the old Cape at 11.30 P.M. blowing fresh and cloudy at 12 (midnight) saw Nauset lights So ends the 24 hours
location: Pond Island, Thatches Island, Cape Cod, Old Cape, Nauset Light

journal_entry: Wind North little Westerly Went by the Pollock Rip Light Ship at 4 A.M. wind hauling Westerly and moderating. passed Cross Rip at 7 A.M. Then took the wind West. and soon after a head tide anchored at Vineyard Haven at 2 P.M.
location: Pollock Rip, Cross Rip, Vineyard Haven

journal_entry: Wind South South West Got underway at day light and went out of Vineyard Haven. At one oclock PM commenced raining and wind breezing Went into Dutch Island at 3.30 P.M. At 6 oclock rain ceased
Wind N.N.W. Commenced getting underway at day light but before the anchor was clear of bottom the wind all gone and calm the remainder of the day. Lay at anchor at Dutch Island
Very moderate. wind from W.S.W. to S.S.W. overcast and rainy No kind of a chance to get out Lay at anchor at Dutch Island
Wind NorthWest and blowing a gale. Laying at Dutch Island all day with both anchors ahead
Wind from NorthWest to West South West. blowing heavy all day. More moderate at night and hove up the second anchor

Wind W.S.East untill 2 PM when it hauled N.West at dark got underway and went out of Dutch Island Harbor. At 8 P.M. abrest of Point Judith. tow the wind Westerly and went back to Dutch Island anchored at 10 PM

Wind North North West got underway at day light at Dutch Island. Wind hauled Easterly and Southerly and very baffling At dark abrest of Watch Hill. Wind hauling West. Went through the Race at 9.15 PM. heavy snow squalls. And at 10.30 PM took the wind North and headed up the Sound and at midnight abt 5 miles East of Long Sand Shoal Light Ship so ends these 24 hours
location: Dutch Island, Watch Hill, Long Sand Shoal Light

journal_entry: Wind North. At 2 am wind hauled W.N.W. and blow at 3 AM took in light sails and was about half way from Long Sand shoal Light ship to Falkners Island and at 5 AM reefed mainsail and at 6 am kept of and went back to New London and at one PM let go second anchor wind blowing a gale
location: Long Sand Shoal Light, Falkners Island, New London

journal_entry: Wind Westerly Got underway at New London in the morning and went out. The wind breezed up so hard went back to New London at 11 A.M.
Wind West South West lay at anchor all day at New London
Got underway at New London at 5 AM wind very light Northerly then Westerly then calm then Southerly. At sunset abrest of Hortons Point At midnight New Haven bore N.W. Not any wind calm
location: New London, Hostons Point, New Haven

journal_entry: Calm on nearby so most all day. At 4 P.M. wind breezed up South East passed Eatons Neck at 10 P.M. midnight calm
Wind Easterly and very moderate at noon passed Everton Rocks at 1.30 P.M. anchored at City Island. to telegraph to N.Y. for order where to haul in to discharge but get no answer to day
location: Everton Rocks, City Island, New York

journal_entry: Wind Southerly and moderate took cars and went to N.Y. and in the afternoon got my orders where to haul in. Got a tug boat and went to City Island and had the Chromo towed to the moth of New town Creek and anchored as it is to late to get into the berth to night
location: New York, City Island, New Town Creek

journal_entry: Wind Southerly. The morning tide being early to tow up the New Town Creek. waited untill afternoon and got the vessel into the dock at dark ready to commence discharging laths
Wind Easterly and Evacuation day holly dar also a rainstorm so no work done in N.Y.
Wind South West Work all day on cargo discharging
Wind SouthWest finished discharging about noon but could not get out the dock on account of the tide being down Neither could I settle with the Consigner as the Survey bill had not been rendered

Wind Westerly also Thanksgiving Towed Chromo out of New Town Creek. made sail and went as far as Robbins Reef. Took tug boat and towed to Elizabeth port arriving at one P.M. at 3.45 commenced loading Coal for Bar Harbor to freight $1.35 per ton and discharged. At 5.15 oclock was loaded with 199 tons. Got ship stores in evening
location: Robbins Reef, Elizabeth Port, Bar Harbor

journal_entry: Wind from South West to West. towed out the coal dock at Elizabeth port in morning. made sail and anchored at the Red Hook at 10 a.m. Went to the City of N.Y. and settled the freight on the load of lumber I brouht here. Sent J.P. Gordon a check for $80 for owners of Chromo Shiped a man got on board at 4 P.M. and am all ready to sail for Bar Harbor
location: Elizabeth Port, Red Hook, New York, Bar Harbor

journal_entry: Wind North North East. Took tug boat in the morning and towed through the gates. Wind hauling Easterly and moderate. At 4 P.M. anchored at City Island And at midnight Wind South West called all hands and got underway at City Island to run down the sound

Wind South West At 1 oclock AM passed Execution Rock At 6 A.M. passed Eatons Neck Wind hauling Westerly. At 10 oclock raining hard Wind West jibed ship at 12 PM. wind N.W. and cleared up. At 1 PM Passed Hortons Point passed through the Race at 3.30 PM wind N.N.W reefed main sail. passed Vineyard and Sound Light ship at 9.30 PM & anchored at Vineyard Haven at midnight wind blowing a gale
location: Execution Rock, Eatons Neck, Hortons Point, Vineyard Haven, Sound Light

journal_entry: Wind NorthWest and blowing fresh Lay at anchor all day at Vineyard Haven

This day begins calm Boon Island bore E.N.E Whales back W.S.W. At 1 AM light air Northerly. headed North Easterly. At noon abrest of Wood Island And at 3 PM took light wind North East and at 9 PM anchored in Portland Roades weather clear
location: Boon Island, Wood Island, Portland Roades

journal_entry: In the morning calm Took the boat and went ashore. at Portland and back on board at 10.30 A.M. Wind S.W. Got underway as soon as got on board and went out. Passed monhegan at 4 PM and anchored at Froy Island at 8 in the evening

Got underway at day. light at Froy Island wind South West arrived at Bar Harbor at 1 P.M. hauled "Chromo" as near the dock as she would come when it was high water, but the tide was not light enough to let her in

Wind South South West At high water in the morning hauled into the wharf and when the vessel took bottom on the ebb tide she broke all the piles of at the end of the Rodic wharf. and there was a crew at work all day repainting the wharf. At night not so rough vessel lay easy
Wind NorthWest. commenced to discharge in the morning at Bar Harbor

Wind North. Commenced work again in the noon to discharge coal and at 3 PM was all discharged soon after dark vessel was afloat sum kedy hauled of made sail and went to Winter Harbor arrived at 9 P.M. wind very moderate when anchored
Wind N.N.W. Did not try to get the Chromo in to the Harbor as the wind was rather seant the vessel was anchored out side of Harbor Point Got stove home & bought of Charles Smith
Wind South West and a very fresh breeze. Went on board the vessel with a crew to get underway to got up into the Harbor. but the wind blew so hard gave it up
Wind South West no chance to get up into the Harbor
Wind NorthWest. Went on board Chromo in a Dora and the Dora parted her painter and went a drift to the Lower Harbor set colors and was rescued by another boat

Wind Easterly. Got G.D.Harrington team started for Franklin to settle with the owners of Chromo. Went as far as Sullivan and Sound J. P. Gordon and he being one of the owners & settled with him. and did not go to Franklin Came home in the afternoon arrived at dark raining hard Good sleighing the first for the season. Took up note held by H L Wooster

Wind North Easterly and snowing most all day. Got sheep home from J. F. Hingsleys. Took my hedding out of the Chromo. and in the evening went to a social at the Hall with my family. the proceeds go towards fencing the grave yard

Wind North. Went to South Gouldsboro to the Sarchine factory to a town meeting to see about the building of a Town House and also the Location of samee In the evening went to the Hall at Winter Harbor to a Lyceum Question Resolved that a single man can live a happier live than a married one. My self first on the affirmative
Wind North East thick with snow all day Reg. letter to O.W. young for $11.72 it being the amount of dividend to 1/16 of Sch. Chromo
Wind North West Staid about home. doing nothing in particular
WInd North West and what is called very cold. The thermometer 15 deg below zero. and did not rise to zero for the day
Wind Easterly and thick with snow all day. Reed Reg letter from Cabbin & Havy

Christmas Calm all day on nearby so and pleasant. Reg letter to Belfast to OW Pitcher Eeg one of the owners of Sch Chromo. sent $11.72 minus of 10 cts for registering the dividend of the last trip for 1883 to 1/16
About calm all day with and air Northerly. Work about home all day

Wind Southerly and warm. Took some coal out Chromo. and getting ready to begin to build a skiff. In the evening went to Lyceum Question Resolved that custom of holding sociables is a greater evil to the community than dancing
Wind SouthWest in morning and hauled Westerly and blew very heavy Chromo draged one anchor. Took coal out of vessel
Wind Northerly. Work on board of the Chromo apart of the day changing anchors
Wind E. N. East. and in the afternoon commenced snowing and at night snowing hard
Wind East North East moderate snow storm. worked apart of the day mooring Sch Chromo of which I have been master for one year Wrote notices for a Hall meeting

Wind East North East and snowy all day. hauled up to the house ton of coal that came out the "Chromo" that I have been in for the past year. Took Sch Egret from the Steam boat wharf and took her to our own wharf to look after the remainder of the winter Price agreed upon $5.00. In the evening went to the Steam boat wharf meeting at Winter Harbor Sleighing good.
Wind East South East. snowing hard and blowing a gale Chromo. dragged one anchor. Got a hawser across the Harbor and kept her from going a shore

Wind West by South and a very fresh breeze. Work on board of Chromo all the forenoon clearing anchors. One garing on board I found she had swung in to the Golden Eagle draged her from her moorings and broke her main boom and done in the night when the wind changed from E.S.E. to West by South

Wind West South West and a very fresh breeze Work apart of the day on a skiff. Schr Lexington Capt. Eugene Nutter got a shore on Harbor point in trying to get in Wind baffling Went to his assistance but he needed no help
Wind NorthWest. Thermometer 10' above zero. Work most all day on a playboat putting sails on for Charley Kingsley
Wind NorthWest and cold thermometer at zero in the morning Intended to go to West Bay to Capt John Moores Funeral but cold and gave it up
Wind NorthWest . made stem for any boat and work about home
Wind NorthWest At night wind went down. Work at J F Kingsleys apart of the day on boat
Wind South Easterly and a terrific storm Sch Egret lying at our wharf had her mainsail entirely blown to pieces

Wind Westerly quite moderate work about home. In the evening went to Lyceum Question Resolve that Industry is more advantageous to man than talent. My self on the affirmative Question decided in the negative
Calm all day damp with rain and snow. Work apart of the day on boat
Wind North East. hauled home from Baker & Smith 1 1/4 cords of hard wood paid for the same In evening storming
Wind Northerly and moderate in the forenoon and Southerly in the afternoon
Wind NorthWest. work most all day on Sch Chromo. placing the anchors anew
Wind NorthWest and cold. Work about home in the forenoon and in the afternoon to J. F. Kingsleys shop to work

Wind West North West and cold work about home in the forenoon, and in the afternoon went to J F. Kingsleys to work he being to West Gouldsboro to get his horse showed. At 1.45 P.M. News came that Mr Kingsley was very sick at West Gouldsboro and was probably dead. Hired team and carried Mr Kingsleys wife to West Gouldsboro, and found he was dead. Came back to Winter Harbor with his horse and the hired team in tow. Got some clothes for Mr Kingsleys as requested and went back to West Gouldsboro. In the evening came home to make arrangements for casket and other things pertaining

Wind Westerly. Ordered casket from the shop Reuben Rand And decided to have J. F. Kingsley burried at Winter Harbor, as it was left with me to decide and marked out the place in the yard. In the afternoon went to West Gouldsboro for further instructions carried Charley (11 years old) son of Mr Kingsley who wanted to see his father. came back at night with Jennil his widow and his son Charley

Wind West South West and pleasant. At 10 oclock in the forenoon sent a team to West Gouldsboro with a casket. Got S. C. Pendleton to dig grave At 2 oclock in the afternoon the casket came back with the remains of J. F. Kingsley carried to his house. Watches for the night Capt G.W. Tracy & Ged Pendleton
Wind North East snow storm. Made preparations for the funeral of J. F. Kingsley. Watches for the night Capt. Peleg Tracy and Capt. Herbert E. Tracy

Wind North East and quite cold. At one PM the relitives of the late J. F. Kingsley began to assemble at his house. At 2 oclock P.M. they formed into a procession and went to the Hall to attend funeral conducted by Mr. Banghart co methodist minister
Wind NorthEast and moderate Commenced moving over to Mrs. Jennil  Kingsleys to assist them in taking care of the sheep and barn during stormy weather
Wind South West work all day moving furniture and stoves over to Mrs Kingsleys and setting them up do not keep house by our selves but all in one family at present
Calm all forenoon work hauling wood for Mrs Kingsley afternoon wind Southerly. went to the Lower Harbor with Capt. G.W. Tracy with house, and got stick to make the Sch American Eagle main boom
Wind Southerly In the forenoon moving things over to Jennil Kingsleys and in the afternoon heavy rain
Wind North. Roads all ice good sleighing Work all day on skiff in shop
Wind North NorthWest. Work in shop on various kinds of work, and getting ready to keep house by our selves
Wind Northerly and cold
Calm all day and in the morning the thermometer below zero. Work all day moving things from the old house to mrs Kingsleys and finished at night

Wind Southerly hauled one load of wood for Mrs Kingsley in the morning and worked the remainder of the day build sink and closet in one part of Mrs Kingsleys house getting ready to keep house by our selves Laura Joy moved in our old house that we have just left
Wind Southerly and weather threatening work all the forenoon building closet, and in the afternoon commenced keeping house by our selves
Wind Southerly Thermometer 40 deg above zero. and looking like rain work in shop on boat all day In the evening went to Spelling School at School house
Wind Southerly untill high water when it came of NorthWest in the afternoon. Finished planking boat
Wind NorthWest untill noon when it hauled out Southerly. Work about home on various kinds of work
Wind NorthWest about home
Wind North East and moderate snow all day Timbered out my boat in shop
Wind East South East and heavy rain all day. Work in shop
Wind out Southerly and rainy all day work in shop jobbing on various kinds of work
Calm all day and overcast hauled up the Chromo yawl boat to repair and sided a stick to make a main boom for Capt G.W. Tracys vessel the "Golden Eagel"
Wind Easterly. moved my sheep from the old place we have left to Mr Kingsleys back field where they may go with her sheeps and be all fed togather. At night painted the inside of my skiff
Dead calm all day and overcast. At night raining Work all the forenoon hauling wood and one turn in the afternoon for Jennil Kingsley from the lot back of the oat field
Wind Northerly about home. Went to a religious meeting in the afternoon
Wind Easterly hauled wood in the forenoon afternoon work in shop
Wind South East and thick with snow. Went to West Gouldsboro with team to get some grain for the horse
Wind South Easterly and rainy all day. Work in forenoon in shop and in the afternoon went down to Mark Island and married Mr. George G Sargent and Mrs Julia H. Joy both of Gouldsboro

Wind Southerly and thick with fog, also rainy. Went to Franklin with Mrs Kingsleys horse to see about freights and other matter. Got back home at dark or a little after the sleighing good the roads being all ice
Wind North West work in shop jobbing most all day
Wind SouthWest turned some posts for Capt Sherman Spurling vessels quarter rail. In the afternoon went to the Barber shop and on board "Chromo" with R Rand to see about the painting of the cabbin
Wind Southerly and fair weather the ice melts in the sun
Wind Easterly and rainy at night commenced snowing Work all day in the shop turned some posts for Capt Spurling ect
Wind Easterly good sledding Finished turning posts for Capt Sherman Spurling in forenoon In the afternoon work on my boat in the shop

Wind South by East and a very fresh breeze hauled wood untill noon from the back lot for Mr Kingsley at 11 oclock it began to rain and rained the remainder of the day. In the afternoon work in shop. put knees in my boat
Wind North West and blew a gale Finished my boat that I have been building this winter Acknowledged bill of sale of the sch Grace Stevens for Capt J A Stevens
Wind North West untill 4 oclock PM when the wind hauled Southerly commenced making boom for GW Tracys vessel
Wind Southerly fresh breeze and heavy rain all day In evening commenced snowing
Wind Northerly Went to a religious meeting in the afternoon at the Hall preaching by M Banghart
Wind Easterly and apart of the day snowy work in the shop

Wind Easterly. At 10 AM Nichols Bunker came from West Gouldsboro and bought Mr Kingsleys horse In the forenoon hauled a load of hay out to the sheep. and in the afternoon work on GW. Tracys boom. snowy
about calm light air changeable moderate. Finished main boom for Capt G.W. Tracy in forenoon and in the afternoon went on board of the Chromo to see about work
Wind Easterly and at noon commenced snowing and at night the toughest snow storm for the winter turned capston bar for vessel and worked in shop. on various kinds of work
Wind Westerly blowing heavy and snowing all day. and is realy a tough day. Went on board the Chromo built two fires heat water & had the cabbin cleaned as it is the intention to have it varnished
Wind West NorthWest. Went on board the "Chromo" built fire and had the cabbin varnished Snow deep roads blocked and shoveled out
Wind Westerly about home

Wind North West. Went to South Gouldsboro to the lobster factory to our anual town meeting which was usualy held at West Bay. but owing to the town house being burned it was called to So Gouldsboro. Jack Donover moderator. Peter L Hill elected Town Clerk Albert Joy, Tobert Joy & Andrew J Gerrish Select men and over seers of the poor
noteworthy: Peter L Hill elected Town Clerk

journal_entry: Wind NorthWest blowing a gale and very cold. to cold to work in the shop as there is no fire. so did not do anything towards getting ready to go away in the vessel except hire a man to go.
Wind NorthWest in forenoon and S.W. in afternoon. made mast for yawl board and turned capstain bar for vessel. ect
Wind Southerly and warm all day. work about the shop most all day
Wind NorthEast and in the afternoon snow hauled a load of hay to the back field, and cleared up the shop chamber
Wind NorthEast Fresh breeze and a heavy snow storm all day and cold. About home doing nothing in particular Mail did not arrive on account of the big storm
Wind North East and heavy snow storm most all day. snow piling in deep. About noon the mail arrived which was due yesterday at 3 P.M.

Wind North East and snowing hard then hauled to the North. and snow drifted bad and decidedly the most snow on the ground no than at any time this winter. made sail over for the yawl boat. Reed John P Gordons check for $100 payal 6 in 3 months
Wind East and hauled around Southerly Had Ship work done for Chromo in forenoon and in the afternoon worked in shop for Capt N. A. Bickford
Wind Southerly and showery all day and in the afternoon a heavy thunder shower. Work about home in shop
Wind SouthWest and pleasant. Work in shop in forenoon turning lounge legs &C For Chas. Straw. In the afternoon work on board "Chromo" shoveling snow. and work on head gear

Wind very moderate Southerly and warm. Took up 4th note of Capt Wm Handy which comes due 28th April next amounting to $123.00 notes given for the home stead of the late Stephen Round. Work about home on various kinds of work

Wind North East and snowing hard. In the afternoon Went to a district meeting at School house. G.W. Tracy moderator GL Nowood Sec. Calm Pendleton School Agent. Also another Notice posted for a district meeting one week from day with an article to divide the School house for two schools which was omited in the Wanaut to day
Wind West North West and pleasant
Wind Southerly Went on board of Chromo and built fire. cleared up cabbin and deck &C
Wind NorthWest. cut wood at the door apart of the day and hauled hay to the sheep

Wind Southerly warm loosed vessels sails Went to Lower Harbor in forenoon in boat and got stick to make boom for Chromo Jib. and in the afternoon tied sails up. today being the first time the sails has been loosed for the winter. In the evening twelve men met at my place of residence to post themselves on Masonry
Wind North East and snowing all day. Work in shop cutting stove wood

Wind North East. Work about home in the forenoon but in the afternoon wind hauled Southerly. Went on board the Chromo and shoveled snow and commenced making boom for jib. Reed letter from Boardman Bros Calais dated 19th saying the ice was about as solid as anything during the winter did not think would break up till 15 or 20 of next month

Wind South West and warm. hauled hay from my barn to Mrs Kingsleys sheep house In the afternoon went to District meeting to see about dividing the School house into two rooms. but the District did not agree and the School house is not to be divided by a partition running through as was in the warrant. and the meeting adjourned
local_place: barn, Mrs Kingsleys sheep house, school house

journal_entry: Wind South South East. Went to a Religious meeting afternoon and evening at the Hall
Wind Southerly and a very heavy rain in morning but beforenoon cleared up and refrained fence In the afternoon went on board "Chromo" to work
Wind moderate North West. Filled two casks water in forenoon and finished making boom for Chrom Jib
Wind Southerly and hauled around Easterly and began to breeze up. took the yawl boat on deck to refrain also launch my new skiff that I built the past winter
Heavy Easterly and rain storm all day put swing up in shop for children
Wind North East rainy all day. took "Chromo" from her winter mornings and placed her along side the wharf and refrained her forefoot
Wind N.N.West. and pleasant. Got ship stores on board in morning and on high water hauled to the head of Steam boat wharf. In the afternoon got underway and went into the Sand Cove
Wind Northerly fresh breeze and snow squalls
Wind North fresh breeze. refrained blush fence for Mrs Kingsley
Wind Northerly and snow squalls work about home getting ready to go away
Wind NorthWest and moderate got underway at 9 A.M. to go to Sullivan. at noon the wind died out and baffled all around the compass. Anchored at Sullivan below the Falls at 3 oclock P.M.
Wind Easterly and rainy all day Chromo dragged  small anchor so she took bottom at half tide when she floated in the afternoon made sail and went over the falls

Wind North North East very fresh breeze in forenoon and showery all day. Went to Franklin to see Mr. J. P. Gordons Agent about loading stone but the wind blowing out from Mr Gordons wharf & cannot get this wharf therefore have decided to load for Portland

Wind North East and showery. Hauled into Crabtree & Harveys wharf in the morning and commenced loading paving blocks for Portland and at night had in 15 blocks The blocks are to fill a Chicago contract and are going through to Chicago by Rail from Portland The freight on stone $10 per 1.000

Wind North Easterly Pilot came on board in the morning and at 9 AM put sail on, and left Sullivan for Portland. Passed Bakers Island at 1PM wind hauled Northerly fine rain. passed Matinicus Rock at 9 P.M. and monhegan at midnight. wind North by West and very overcast. So ends these 24 hours
location: Sullivan, Portland, Bakers Island, Matinicus Rock

journal_entry: Wind North by west and rainy arrived at Portland Head at 8 AM and beat into Portland. Got berth at noon and in the afternoon discharged 1700 blocks with a horse
Wind North North East. and overcast with a little rain. Worked in the forenoon discharging paving blocks but in the afternoon the wharf was blocked and did not work
Wind North East. overcast and showery but did not rain hard and worked all day discharging with a horse

Wind Easterly and rained quite hard all day. so hard the horse did not come to work and we discharged by hand. and at 4 P.M. had them all out except about 800. which we have out in the evening when the tide was up. The Chromo had on board 14.952 a fall short by 48 blocks

About calm in the morning hauled through the bridges then went a shore and settled for my freight. At 6 oclock PM a light air SouthWest got underway and went out of Portland for Sullivan At midnight abrest of Seguin
Wind Westerly and fine weather. passed Matinicus Rock at 8.30 A.M. and Bar Harbor at 6 P.M. when took the wind North West. and anchored above Crabtrees Neck at 8 PM bound to Sullivan
location: Matinicus Rock, Bar Harbor, Crabtrees Neck, Sullivan

journal_entry: Wind NorthWest. Got underway in the morning at Crabtrees Neck and went to Sullivan anchored below the falls
Wind NorthWest. Agreed to load for Simpson & Abbott with block paving for New York at $20 per. At 10 AM took tug and towed over the falls at Simpson & Abbots wharf and at 2 PM commenced loading
Wind South Easterly Finished loading at night. two late to get over the Falls. had on board 12.900 In the evening commenced raining
Wind South East blowing a gale and very heavy rain all forenoon. In the afternoon moderate took tug and towed over the Falls and anchored fog very thick

Wind Easterly and thick with fog. Got underway in the morning and went out of Sullivan for home fog lighted when abrest of Stone Island. at 10 AM and the wind moderated. tried to get outside of Iron Bound and wind all died out and was also rough. Got back into Stave Island Harbor and anchored at fark this day has been rainy and foggy
weather_condition_am: thick with fog, rough, foggy, rainy

journal_entry: Wind E.N.E thick and rainy also fresh breeze Got underway in the morning at Stave Island and went to Winter Harbor anchored in Sand cove Went in after a cook got none this day Acknowledge died for N. Hammond
North Easterly wind thick and rainy Shiped GL Norwood Cook in the afternoon lay at anchor in Sand cove Winter Harbor. turned belaying pins for Chromo
Wind North Eaterly vessel lay at anchor in Sand cove

very moderate wind Northerly thick with fog and rainy. Got underway at Winter Harbor for New York at noon becalmed of Bakers Island. At 3 P.M. wind breezed up North strong fog cleared. Anchored at Deer Isle at 6 P.M. In the evening rainy and thick
location: Winter Harbor, New York, Bakers Island, Deer Isle

journal_entry: Wind Northerly fresh breeze got underway at Deer Isle at daylight and went out. At noon becalmed 5 miles west from Monhegan In the afternoon at 2 oclock wind breezed up W.S. West. and hauled Northerly at midnight becalmed think we are about half way from Monhegan to Cape Ann. So ends these 24 hours

Chromo becalmed about half way from Monhegan to Thatchers Island. At 3 AM wind breezed up Westerly. at 11 AM saw Cape Cod noon becalmed afternoon wind Southerly. Saw the Sch Kalmer Capt H.E. Tracy. the small boat was put over board and went on board stayed to supper & went back on board Chromo. Not liking the looks of the weather we lay by between Race point and Cape Cod untill 11 P.M. when made sail. midnight abrest of the Old Cape Light
location: Monhegan, Thatchers Island, Cape Cod, Old Cape

journal_entry: This day begins with the wind Southerly but a day light becalmed between the Old Cape Light and Naucetts In the afternoon moderate Easterly Passed by the Pollock Rip Light Ship at 5 oclock in the afternoon and the Handkerchief at 8P.M. At 10 PM heavy rain thick and very dark. At midnight Abrest of Cape Poge Wind North East and rainy So ends these 24 hours
location: Old Cape Light, Pollock Rip, Handkerchief, Cape Poge

journal_entry: Wind North East and very dark with rain. Passed Vineyard Haven at once oclock A.M. Tarpaulin Cove at 2 AM Vineyard Sound Light Ship at 4 oclock AM. weather cleared up And at 10 AM Passed through the Race into Long Island Sound. At midnight becalmed thick with fog and rain. heard the whistle on Falkners Island bearing North and the tide turning a head
location: Vineyard Haven, Tarpaulin Cove, Long Island Sound, Falkner Island

journal_entry: At day light a little wind from the North. and at 6 AM got back abrest of Falkners Island where we were at midnight wind breezing and hauling Easterly passed Eatons Neck at 12.45 PM Execution Rocks at 3 PM Frogs Point at 4PM and anchored at Rickers Island at 5 P.M. at dark calm
location: Falkners Island, Eatons Neck, Execution Rock, Frogs Point, Rickers Island

journal_entry: Wind SouthEasterly Towed through the Gates from Rickers Island to Jersey Flats

Wind South South East Went on shore at N.Y. to find out where to haul in. and in the afternoon Got to the dock out side of another vessel up the North River to manhattanville at the foot of 134th St but will have to wait for another vessel to discharge
Wind NorthWest. Chromo lying outside of another vessel waiting for her turn to discharge Went to town and got a coal order to load at Weehawker for Ipswick at $1.05 per ton and discharged
Wind NorthWest and fresh breeze. Got into the wharf in the forenoon, and in the afternoon commenced discharging stone

Wind South East Chromo all discharged before noon and in the afternoon went to the coal dock at Weehawken to load with coal for Ipswich freight $1.05 and disch Get two checks on the Marine National Bank one for $100 No 7848 for Owner of Chromo and one for $20 No 78.49 to send to my wife
Wind South East Sent check from the Marine National Bank to my wife No 7849 Chromo receiving coal all day from canal boats

Wind Westerly Finished loading coal at Weehawken at 10 AM and took boat to Haboken where the tow was made up and in the afternoon towed through the Gates Wind hauling Southerly at 8 oclock PM passed Eatons Neck and at 10 P.M. passed the middle ground when the wind died out. and midnight no wind

Very moderate South Westerly wind and thick with smoke no land to be seen. At 1.30 in forenoon vessel took bottom and stopped. The small boat was put out and it was ascertained the vessel was on the Northern part of a shovel and the tide nearly down. Soon after the smoke cleared and we saw Hortons Point bearing ENE. On the flood tide wind breezed up W.SW and the vessel being headed from the shoal that when the tide got up at 4 P.M. she came of without any damage. Passed the Little Gull Light. at the Race at 9 oclock P.M. the sky very cloudy wind moderate showery. At midnight abrest of Watch Hill. So much smoke cannot see a great way so ends these 24 hours.
location: Hortons Point, Little Gull Light, Watch Hill

journal_entry: Wind South South West. Passed Block Island at 3 A.M. And the Vineyard Sound at 11 AM Then the wind baffling easy way some times calm. Anchored in Tarpaulin Cove at dark
location: Block Island, Vineyard Sound, Tarpaulin Cove

journal_entry: Wind Easterly and foggy Got underway in the Morning to beat to Vineyard Haven. but before we got there the tide turned to run Westerly and although the wind breezed up did not get into Vineyard Haven untill the tide turned Easterly in the afternoon then fresh breeze and raining hard
Wind Easterly fresh breeze and in the afternoon heavy rain At night let go the second anchor

Wind Easterly thick with fog and rain Lay at anchor all day in Vineyard Haven. At night wind N.N. East. On going a shore to dat took up a Boston paper and there learned that the two checks I had got at the Marine Natural, Bank in N.Y. were considered worthless as the Bank had failed

Tremendous heavy thunder and rain just before day light at 8 am wind northerly and got underway at 9 AM and went out of Vineyard Haven. At noon took wind SouthWest Passed Cross Rip Light Ship at one P.M. and Handkerchief Light Ship at 3 PM. Passed Pollock Rip at 4.10 PM Nausett at 7 PM and the Old Cape at 8.40 PM. At midnight a little more than halfway over to Thatchers Island. The sky full of fog so ends these 24 hours
location: Vineyard Haven, Cross Rip Shoa, Pollock Rip, Handkerchief, Thatchers Island, Old Cape, Nausett

journal_entry: Wind South West and overcast at 5.30 AM at the mouth of Ipswick River set colors for Pilot. and at 8 am one came on board and waited until 10 am for the ride to get up and went in over the bar and anchored at 11 A.M. Took the little boat and rowed to Ipswick a distance of the Miles to report get letters Re. Heavy thunder showers the remainder of the day. Made arrangements with Capt of tug boat to tow Chromo up first chance Reed letter from H.W. Baker an Attorney in Boston requesting the immediate payment of Chromo tow bill for towing on the Hennebee in Nov. 1883. Whereas it had been agreed in writing that the towage shovels be paid by the shippers of lumber

Wind West North West Fresh breeze Took steam boat and towed from the Motuh of Ipswich River to the town of Ipswich. hauled into the wharf above the one where we are going to discharge as the Schr Mark Gray to discharge coal and we must wait our turn

Wind Northwest fresh breeze lay at the wharf in Ipswich waiting for the Schr Mark Gray to discharge Telegraphed to W.H. Juvett & Co Gardiner Me to Setttle the Chromo's tow bill and save expense. Got answer they would attend to it at once

Wind Northerly and went around Easterly When the tide was up in the afternoon. The Sch Mark Gray was discharged and we took her place and scevedores commenced to discharge at 3 P.M. In the evening went to the Skating Rink Ipswich Mass
Wind North East and in the forenoon heavy rain. but the Stevedores went to work discharging coal. afternoon cleared up

Wind NorthWest in the morning. Chromo was discharged at 9 oclock A.M. Settled for freight At noon got ship stones at at 2 oclock in the afternooon took tow boat and towed from Ipswich to Sea. Wind struck South East and gradually hauled back Westerly. At 8.30 passed Boon Island Leidge At midnight abrest of Cape Elizabeth when the wind Struck South
