Wind South and overcast At 6 oclock AM Passed Monhegan bound to Winter Harbor Me. At 8 AM passed White Head and 12 oclock M passed Bass Harbor and anchored at Winter Harbor at 2 P.M. At night rainy
Wind Southerly lay at anchor at Winter Harbor as I did not want to go away to stop over sunday. Put up notices to warn people against crossing the fields where ever they like
Wind North West and very fresh breeze to much wind to beat to Sullivan if I wanted to go
Calm in the morning Got underway and when the wind breezed up went to Sullivan to have some work done on Chromo and to load after the work was done
Wind Southerly Took small boat and went to Franklin and got a stick to make a new head on mainmast and telegraphed to John C. Reed of Ellsworth to come tomorrow mom and take the mast out

Wind South East & raining in torrents all forenoon. At one pm held up the Riggor commenced putting up shears to take the mainmast out as the mast head is very rotten. A caulken also began spinning oakum getting ready & caulk
Wind Southerly and thick with fog. Took mainmast out Chromo in the forenoon. And in the afternoon commenced splicing the head
Wind South East and raining all day. done nothing toward putting a new head on mast but repaired the Crosstree in shop at Sullivan
Wind Southerly and showery most all day but worked on mast head
Wind NorthWest in forenoon and Southerly in the afternoon. Chromo laid at the wharf in Sullivan
Wind West South West very fresh breeze Finished splicing mast head of Chromo. While the caulkers are at work on her top
Wind Southerly and moderate. Chromo mast ready to set. but no rigor come but the caulkers still at work
Wind North East and steady rain after 9 oclock A.M. At noon the rigor came took the Main standing in the hold and refilled it. No oakum  drove after 9 A.M.
Wind N.N.East. Riggor set mast in forenoon sent up topmast and went home to Ellsworth in the afternoon two caulkers working all day

Wind Northerly work all day on vessel rigging her up after getting the mast back caulking Ice & burned my hand very bad with boiling hot pitch  by its sloping out of kettle in carrying it from the fire to the vessel for the caulkers to use in the evening went to see Dr Brigham who recomended linseed oil and lime water for my hand

Wind SouthWest fresh breeze the caulkers finished work on vessels top and in the afternoon got a team and went home. hand swelled very bad caused by the burning done with hot pitch the whole back of my hand is blistered

Wind Southerly and very moderate. Staid at home all day the Vessel at Sullivan the stain on these frages  is caused by the Linseed oil used on my hand for the care of the burn as if keep linseed oil and lime water on as was recommended by Dr Brigham

Wind Easterly. Went back to Sullivan in the morning and when I got there the Chromo had just gone over the Halls with the tug boat so I went to West Sullivan and joined the vessel at the Hopewell wharf In the afternoon took on board 2200 blocks of paving for N.Y. at night rainy
Wind North Easterly and showery reed on board 3100 blocks. Loading for Simpson &Abbott for N.Y. at 20 per

Wind Northerly fresh breeze hauled into Simpson & Abbotts wharf in the afternoon and took in 3000 blocks. The swelling going down on out of my hand that was caused by burning done by hot pitch and is doing nicely can use it some
Wind Southerly and moderate. Finished loading at night had on board 13.000 blocks. hauled from the wharf in the River at night
Calm untill noon Towed down over the Falls at 11 AM At noon wind breezed up Southerly beat down to Stave Island Harbor a little before sun set and anchored and walked home

Calm. Walked from home back to Chromo at Stave Island in morning. At 11 oclock A.M. wind breezed up South got underway and beat out and at 4 PM abrest of Turtle Island head wind moderate Went into Winter Harbor and anchored
location: Stave Island, Turtle Island, Winter Harbor

journal_entry: Calm in morning wind Southerly in afternoon. Lay at anchor all day at Winter Harbor. thick with fog out side and rough
Wind from South to SouthWest Got underway at Winter Harbor in forenoon and beat out fog came in thick anchored at Bass Harbor at 6 oclock PM
Wind North East and overcast. Got underway at day light at Bass Harbor. Passed White Head at 11 oclock AM Monhegan at 2.30 PM Wind East and vessel running straight for Cape Cod

Wind Easterly Sighted Cape Cod at 7 oclock A.M. when it began to grow thick at noon passed the whistling buoy N.E. from the Pollock Rip Passed Vineyard Haven at 6 P.M. and theViney and Sound Light Ship at 10.30 P.M. midnight moderate and thick bound across Block Island Channel
location: Cape Cod, Pollock Rip, Vineyard Haven, Block Island

journal_entry: Wind Easterly and thick with fog. At 6 am passed the whistling buoy North from Block Island Passed through the Race at 11 A.M. the fog lifting for a few minutes. Afternoon and evening calm. midnight Falkners Islands bore West North West about 5 miles distant.

Calm and thick with fog. At 8 oclock AM fog lifted. the wind breezed up North East and Falkners Island bore North Passed the middle ground at 10.30 A.M. and Eatons Neck at one PM Execution Rock at 6 oclock P.M. And anchored at 9 P.M.
location: Falkners Island, Eatons Neck, Execution Rock

journal_entry: Wind North East. took tug boat early in the morning at Rickers Island and towed through the Gates and up the Hudson River to Manhattan Ville at 131st Street the place where we are going to discharge but on arriving find 5 vessels inside of the Chromo and I must take away my turn
Wind Southerly Went to Jersey City to see Hugh McDonald but could not find him and went back on board

Wind Southerly Went to town after a freight to go East with after the vessel is discharged bound non. Reed letter from Hugh McDonald one of owners of Chromo stating he was at Weehawken. Went to his boarding house at Weekawken and stopped with him all night

Wind Southerly. After breakfast at Weehawken went across to New York to see if there are any freights to go East with but formed non. took the Elevated Rail Road and went back to the Chromo at Manhattan ville
Wind South West Nothing to do but wait for other vessels who lay inside of ours to discharge
Wind Northerly in the morning and Southerly in the afternoon
Wind SouthWest and very hot the thermometer 90 in the shade buby waiting
wind southerly and very hot the thermometer 92 in the shade Got a berth along side of wharf but it was to late to begin work
Wind South Easterly Lying along side of wharf at 131 St ready to discharge
Commenced discharging in the morning but the wharf was kept blocked all day and did not get discharged 30 tons. Wind South East all day. fresh

Wind South South East Finished discharging stone at 9.30 A.M. and hauled out and when the tide turned Ebb at noon the mate got the vessel under way and beat down to Haboken where she is going to load coal. Where I stopped to Settle freight
Wind South Easterly hauled into the wharf in forenoon and commenced loading coal in afternoon for Salem freight $1.10
Wind Easterly and heavy rain untill noon. Finished loading at 10 A.M. and hauled of to an anchor already to sail but the wind blow to heavy to move

Wind Easterly and clear. Towed through the gates in forenoon made sail and beat down the Sound at noon abrest of Frogs Point and at dark anchored at Oyster Bay above Eatons Neck the tide turning ahead
location: Frogs Point, Oyster Bay, Eatons Neck

journal_entry: Got anchor at Oyster Bay at day light. Wind moderate Easterly At dark abrest of the middle ground almost becalmed midnight becalmed a little past the middle ground near Stratford Com

Calm untill day light when a very light air of wind came from the westward then a little to the Eastward of the middle ground At 2 oclock PM abrest of Falkners Island. Wind hauled Southerly Passed through the Race when the sun was setting and at midnight Block Island bore South Wind South West

Wind South West and while in Vineyard Sound the fog came in thick did not know where we passed Tarpaulin Cove. Afterward heard the Whistle on West Chol and passed East Chat at 12 M fog sealed and went of the Shoals passed the Pollock RIp Light Ship at 3.30 P.M. Passed Cape Cod at 8.30 P.M. thick with fog but herd the whistle and know when we passed it. midnight some where above halfway from the Cape up is Salem. So ends these 24 hours
location: Vineyard Sound, Tarpaulin Cove, Shoals, Pollock Rip Light, Cape Cod, Salem

journal_entry: Wind SouthWest and thick with fog. At 5 AM made beakers and have to and at 7 AM made Egg Rock kept of and run for Salem and anchored at Salem at 9 AM but the tide was down and could not get to the wharf At 4 PM took tug boat and tried to get to the wharf but there is not 10 feet water in Rip and could not get there In evening went to Barnham Show

Wind SouthWest took the cars and went to New Bedford to see the Schr Sarah Wooster with the understanding to repair her for one half of her if thought best. It bein to late to go back to Salem I staid at New Bedford over night. but have not decided to repair her

Wind North Easterly and hot took cars and went back to Salem But the Chromo had not got into the wharf. The tug boat had been to her but not being water enough could not get in At night tide have her part way in with the capstan
Celebration day wind North East. Grand boat race place of starting was from a line drawn from the Chromo stern to the opposite shore. Not tide enough to get to the wharf vessel in mid channel
Wind Westerly fine weather. Hove in the vessel all the high water but could not get her into the wharf for there was not tide enough. but got her part way
Wind Westerly fresh breeze and fine weather. Hove the vessel into the wharf at 10.30 in the evening
Wind Northerly and Easterly. Commenced discharging coal in the morning and finished at night. Got one days demurage $16.32
Wind Easterly hauled down through the bridges and towed of inthe Harbor and anchored at 3 oclock in the afternoon

Wind Northerly Got underway in the morning at Salem E.N.E was all could up rough noon wind died out At 3 PM was neat Eastern pont had drifted back then took wind South West and passed. Thatchers Island at 4 P.M. and at 7 PM becalmed very rough and heavy rain. And at 9 pm cleared up so we saw Thatchers Dscamed legke And at midnight wind began to breeze up Westerly. Thatchers Island about 10 miles dis

Wind Westerly. good breeze. at 8 am died out and came North Easterly. At noon Wind South Easterly It is useless to try to keep record of the wind this day as it is not two hours the same At 3 P.M. Sighted Monhegan and tried to get out side of Matinicus Rock. but taking the wind Easterly could not with a heavy sea running and drifted in South East from Monhegan and at midnight Monhegan bore SouthWest. vessel becalmed

Wind South and Easterly and in fact every other way went into the mussel Ridges at 10 am. At noon at Froy Island. At 4 PM at Yorks Narrows and at 9.30 P.M. anchored of Lopedes Head near Bass Harbor. becalmed not wind enough to get by the head into the Harbor
location: Froy Island, Yorks Narrows, Bass Harbor

journal_entry: Calm and thick with fog. in the morning with a thunder shower. Got underway and anchored again at Bass Harbor not wind enough to get out the Harbor
Calm all the forenoon At noon got underway at Bass Harbor moderate wind. anchored at Sullivan at Sun set thick with fog most all day
Very moderate Northerly Went to Franklin by land after a load for the Chromo. Got non Came back to Sullivan and chartered with Simpson & Abbott to load with block paving for New York Showery
Wind North fresh breeze hauled the Chromo on Mosleys beack in Sullivan Cleaned and painted one side of her bottom Got team and went home at night

Wind Northerly Went from home back to Sullivan with team Cleaned and painted one side of the Chromo bottom. on Mosleys beach took tug boat and towed over the falls to Simpson & Abbott wharf at Sun set ready to load tomorrow morning
Wind Northerly Commenced loading block paving. for Simpson & Abbott. took on 10.000 in numb
Wind SouthWest Finished loading paving blocks and hauled from the wharf

Wind Southerly and heavy rain in the morning. At 9 A.M. towed down over the Falls. made sail and beat out the Bay. At 4.30 between Egg Rock and Turtle Island head very rough. could not beat by the head on flood tide. Keped of went through Turtle Isle Gap and anchored at Winter Harbor at 5.30
location: Egg Rock, Turtle Island, Turtle Isle Gap, Winter Harbor

journal_entry: Wind Southerly terrific thunder storm untill day light when the fog closed in thick Chromo lying in the Sand Cove could not get out

Calm early in the morning at 7 A.M. light air NNW Got underway at Winter Harbor and went out for New York. The Northerly wind lasted as far as Turtle Island Head when took the wind moderate South West. At 6 oclock P.M. abrest of Long Island Head. Rain squalls. Wind hauled Westerly very rough. took in all light sails. My wife has taken a trip for New York this time with me the first one for the Seasons except one to Portland in the Spring
location: Winter Harbor, New York, Turtle Island, Long Island Head, Portland

journal_entry: Wind Westerly and very rough At 7 AM Matinicus Rock bore NorthWest. Lat at noon 43 (degrees) -26 Lat of Matinicus Rock 43 (minutes) -46. making miles Southern. At 4 PM tacked ship headed N.N.W. At 7 P.M. took wind NW tacked ship gave sheet at 10 PM wind headed vessel of to S.S.W.midnight wind W by S

Wind Westerly Chromo by the wind heading from S.S.W to S. at 10 am tacked ship headed West. Lat at noon 42.15 Lat of Cape Cod 42.02 and a west course by compass will seen us to Race point. distance about 40 miles by reckoning and the vessel is running west with a 5 knot breeze. At 8 pm. was abrest of Race Point. wind hauling westerly tacked ship and at 9.30 anchored under the lee of the Old Cape
location: Cape Cod, Old Cape, Race Point

journal_entry: Wind West very fresh breeze. Got underway at 5 oclock AM abrest of Cape Cod Light House. at sunset anchored abrest of Cape Poge Light House tide turned ahead and nearly calm

Light air of wind Northerly and Easterly Got underway at Cape Poge at day light rainy. Wind lasted us to get to the Vineyard Sound Light Ship when it died out. Calm. and in the afternoon light air South West. At 8 P.M. tacked ship near Point Judith wind west. midnight between Point Jude and block Island
location: Cape Poge, Vineyard Sound, Point Judith, Block Island

journal_entry: Wind Northerly and hauling Easterly. Passed through the Race at 8 am. Falkners Island at noon wind East and clear At 8 P.M. between the middle ground and Old Field Wind South Easterly At midnight abrest of Eatons Neck So ends these 24 hours
location: Falkners Island, Old Field, Eatons Neck

journal_entry: Wind Easterly Anchored at Rickers Island at 8 A.M. and at 11 A.M. took tug boat and towed through the Gates raining hard towed to the clock at 51 st Street arriving at 4 oclock P.M.
Wind Southerly Could not get next to the clock to discharge
Wind Southerly Got into the berth in the afternoon to discharge but it was to late for Stevedores to begin work. At night wind came of Northerly

Wind Southerly commenced discharging cargo of stone. Went to town in the forenoon and took a coal order (without any help of a broker). to go Portsmouth N.H. with a load of coal freight $1.10 to be loaded at Port Johnston. In the afternoon went to Coney Island with my wife Took the Steamer on the North River and went to Bay Ridge then took the Cars to Coney Island Came back at night to the Chromo. The fare for Gentleman 40 cents and return. And for ladies 35 cts. Received letter today that Stella Our girl at home is sick but on the mending hand
location: Portsmouth, Port Johnston, Coney Island, Bay Ridge

journal_entry: Wind South Easterly and in the afternoon rainy Finished discharging stone at 10 AM but the flood tide commencing to run could not get down River. At 7 P.M. took tug boat and went to Port Johnston to load coal

Wind Southerly. Chromo at Port Johnston The coal order was carried in the coal office in the morning but they were not ready for vessel. Went to N.Y. and settled for my freight. back at night vessel hauled into the dock but no coal
Wind Southerly and hot went to town with my wife. and when we came  back in the afternoon the vessel was loaded but two late to go through the Gates very hot at night no sleep

Wind Southerly Took tugboat at 2 oclock AM to tow through the gates Anchored at Rickers Island at 8 A.M. At noon the wind breezed up and got underway. Passed Eatons Neck at 6 PM Old Field and Middle Ground at 10 PM Midnight partially foggy wind light
location: Rickers Island, Eatons Neck, Old Field

journal_entry: The wind Southerly and thick with fog passed through the Race at 11 AM without seeing Race Rock and run for Vineyard Sound. At 6 oclock P.M. heard the whistle on the Lightship At 7 PM Passed the Vineyard sound Lightship and anchored at Vineyard Haven at 9.30 PM
Wind Southerly thick and showery. lay at anchor all day at Vineyard Haven

Wind Southerly got underway in the morning at Vineyard Haven and went down toward the Cross Rip. And the fog rolled in so heavy. went back to Cape Poge and lay by untill noon. Frog lighted and run for the Cross Rip again but the fog soon came in but run as far as the Hand kerchief Light Ship but did not see her and anchored night comming on and the fog as thick as an be
location: Vineyard Haven, Cross Rip, Cape Poge, Hankerchief

journal_entry: Wind Southerly Got underway near the Handkerchief Light ship and went down over the Shoals Finsing each Light Ship by their bell on Whistle passing the Pollock Rip at 9 AM and at 10 AM the wind all died out & the tide turned ahead & we anchored on mile N.E. of Light ship. At 4 pm wind breezed up Easterly The fog whistles never ceasing. At 6 PM got anchor and went back as far as the Handkerchief when took the wind in all directions with tremendous rain. and anchored heavy blow and rain till midnight wind S.
location: Handkerchief, Isle of Shoals, Pollock Rip

journal_entry: Wind blew Southerly and rained untill day light when it cleared up. wind from the N.N.E Got anchor and laid by during the day. but anchored again at night calm. At 10 oclock PM a light air of wind N.W. Got anchor and headed Easterly Wind hauling Northerly

Wind North East beat of the Shoals with the hope the wind would haul out. but after beating most all day between the Pollock Rip and Chatham found the wind was in no hurry to change so run back to Edgartown wind very fresh NorthEast anchored at 8 oclock P.M.
Wind North East fresh breeze. Went ashore and mailed letters
Wind North East. rainy in morning lay at anchor at Edgartown Mass
WInd North Easterly. No chance to get East and lay at Edgartown
Wind N.N.E. very fresh breeze and heavy rain in morning

Wind Northerly. Got underway and went out of Edgartown at noon wind died out and when the tide turned westerly was abrest of Handkerchief Light ship 5 PM anchored. At 10 pm tide turned East Got anchor and went of shoals by Pollock Rip at 12 midnight

Wind hauled from north to NorthEast. and at 8 am abrest of Nausett and at 6 oclock PM was abrest of the Old Cape Light. At midnight about half way from the Old Cape to Thatchers Island. wind all died out. and it thick with fog
location: Nausset, Old Cape Light, Thatchers Island

journal_entry: Calm on nearly so from the beginning of this day untill afternoon when the wind breezed up N.E. At day light the fog cleared up and saw Thatchers Island. And when night came the fog came. and at 10 oclock PM passed Thatchers Island. heard the whistle and judged to be about 2 miles of

Wind very moderate Southerly and fog very thick. At noon fog cleared. and the wind breezed. took pilot of whales Back and went into Portsmouth at 3 oclock in the afternoon along side the wharf the air very hot

Wind Southerly and the hottest day in Portsmouth the Thermometer on board the Chromo 92 in the cabbin. I refused to let my Consignees the Concord E.E. Co. discharge the vessel as they wanted 25 cts per ton and I hired an outside Stevedore to discharge for 20 cts per ton. Wherefore my consignees said no more but themselves should do the worl at any price My Stevedore bought his Engine along side in a scow fired up. rigged up his gear. ready to go to work. When the Concord Rail Road Company foe bid his using their stage on the wharf I took council and found it no use. And the consequence I paid my Stevedore $10.00 to leave and paid My Consignee 25 cts per ton to discharge loosing the $10 and one days time

Wind Easterly. My Consignee commenced discharging the Chromo but did not quite finish. The Stevedore that I hired yesterday could have discharged the vessel had he gone to the expence of getting timber and plank and building a stage and then the Consignee would not receive anymore of it a day than what they were oblige to

Wind E.S.E. and the fog very thick. Chromo discharged at 8 oclock AM. no chance to sail. have telegraphed to Gardwin and Addison. for a freight and have heard from there Nothing satisfactory And I make up my mind to go back to Sullivan and take my chances for a load

Calm in forenoon but in the afternoon wind breezed up Southerly. Took tug boat Clara Bateman and towed down. Cast of from the tug boat at 3 PM fresh breeze. Saw lights on Cape Elizabeth at 7 PM passed Monhegan at midnight. So ends these 24 hours

Wind SouthWest passed Matinicus Rock Light at 2 oclock AM Anchored at Sullivan 11 AM In the afternoon went to West Sullivan to see about a load but got none At night rainy thick with fog Crew all discharged and paid of soon as sails were furled at Sullivan
location: Matinicus Rock Light, Bar Harbor, Crabtrees Neck, Sullivan

journal_entry: Wind Southerly and thick with fog. Got ready to go home in the forenoon and at 11.45 AM took the Steamer Electra for home accompanied by my wife who has been the trip to N.Y. with me. Arrived home at 2.30 P.M. by the way of Bar Harbor

Wind South West in the morning but in the afternoon the wind was northWest with as fresh breeze Mrs Jennie Kingsley finished haying and will commence teaching the district Schoal in this place as assistant tomorrow morning
Wind NorthWest fresh breeze. Took the Str Elector at 2.40 PM for Sullivan to join the Chromo. At night the wind South West
Wind South At 9 oclock AM commenced raining Went from the Chromo below the falls to West Sullivan after a freight but got none. Came back in the afternoon to the vessel

Wind North North West and fine work all day on vessel painting and working on boat In the evenin went to a Political lecture in front of the Hotel St John South side. the speaker was out United States. Seniter the Hon Wave P. Frye. Republican
Wind Southerly Painted the Chromo quarter in the forenoon then took the Str Electa and went home to stay untill the first of next week when Mr J. H. West will have a load of stone to go to Providence
Wind Southerly about home all day. In the afternoon rainy
Wind Southerly and thick with fog cleared up the foor yard and put wood in the shop
Wind South and thick with fog. At 2.40 P.M. took the Steamer Little Butter Cup that runs to Winter Harbor tp day instead of the Electa and went to Sullivan to go on board of the Schr Chromo
Wind Northerly and fine weather. No tug boat came over the Falls and so the Chromo lays all day below the Falls. Cleared the anchors and have one up. At night wind South West. Shiped Bowder Murphy
Wind Westerly in the morning. Towed to Franklin abreast of Taunton wharf and anchored afternoon wind Southerly Rigged sail on yawl boat.
Wind Southerly Commenced loading small block paving for Portsmouth shiped by J H West loading from scows for the round sum of $260 with the privilege of the shipper putting on board Edgestone
Wind SouthWest Received two scow loads of paving on board vessel
Wind South South West work loading the Chromo with block paving and edgestone

Wind Southwest. Took on all the block paving and edgestone there is to go in this cargo at Franklin remainder of the load will come on board at West Sullivan. In the afternoon took yawl boat and went from Franklin to West Sullivan hired team and went home with the intention not going on board the Chromo again untill after State Election
Wind Easterly Staid about home all day

Wind very moderate Southerly. Went to the State Election in the forenoon. The new Town house beated at West Gouldsboro and this is the first time it was even used. In the afternoon went to West Sullivan and found the Chromo towing down from Franklin to West Sullivan

Calm in forenoon thick with fog afternoon wind Southerly Finished loading Chromo with edgestone. Sent O.W. Young Esq 8.77 in Reg letter the dividend to 1/16 of Sch Chromo. Got bill of Laden fromJ. H. West

Calm. I have decided I can take more stone and have taken 75 ft more edgestone. At 3 oclock P.M. took the tug boat and went over the Falls wind fresh South East made sail and went out the Bay. and anchored at Winter Harbor at midnight
Wind East to South East got underway at 8 am and went out of Winter Harbor for Babtucket at 9 am thick with fog and out 10 am commenced raining anchored at Deer Isle at 1.45 P.M. the fog very thick

Wind NorthWest. Got underway at Deer Isle at daylight and beat through Froy Island Thorough fare at noon. Passed Monhegan at 450 P.M. when gave a little sheet wind fresh. and hauling Northerly. midnight wind N.N.E winged the vessel out vessel about half way from Monhegan to Cape Cod so ends these 24 hours
location: Deer Isle, Froy Island, Monhegan, Cape Cod

journal_entry: Wind North North East moderate. when the sun rose saw Cape Cod from aloft Passed Naucett at 3 P.M. and went on the Shoals when the sun set at 8 P.M. rain squalls wind fresh took in all light sails wind North. At midnight half way from Vineyard to Tarpaulin Cove so ends these 24 hours
location: Cape Cod, Nausett, Shoals, Vineyard Haven, Tarpaulin Cove

journal_entry: Wind Northerly and the tide ahead passed Vineyard Sound Light Ship at 3 oclock AM and at 4.45 passed Brentons Reef Light Ship bound to Pantucket at noon abrest of Dutch Island wind ahead. In the afternoon wind South West anchored at Providence just before sunset
location: Vineyard Sound Lightship, Dutch Island, Providence

journal_entry: Wind South Westerly When the tide was right in the afternoon Towed Chromo from Providence to Pawtucket
Wind SouthWesterly On account of having a part of a load of stone on board that was not ordered this day goes by and nothing alone to discharging vessel am in hopes to arrive at something tomorrow

Wind South West. As I could not induce the Consignee to take the Curb stone on edge stone. I have got them discharged and hauled away for 6 1/2 cts per boat where why can lay one year without further expence. The block paving I have not troubled yet. but shall discharge them tomorrow
Wind North Easterly Chromo discharged at 2 oclock P.M. Collected freight on one the whole or $260 by the lump sum as per bill of laden In the evening heavy rain

Wind North East Towed from Pawtucket to Providence in the forenoon and went at shore got the New flying jin and bent it the vessel caught aground and when she floated at at 5 oclock PM got underway and at midnight anchored at Dutch Island Calm. bound to Sullivan Maine

Wind South South West. Got underway at Dutch Island at 7 am. when turned to rum out Anchored at Vineyard Haven at 5 oclock PM the weather looking very bad At 8 P.M. wind came of N.W. blew heavy hauled down all sail

Wind North North West Fresh breeze. hauled North Easterly and out and in the afternoon breezed at South South West. Got underway at Vineyard Haven and went by East Chop at 4 P.M. passed the Pollock Rip Light Ship at 10 PM and at midnight abrest of Chatham
location: Vineyard Haven, East Chop, Pollock Rip, Chatham

journal_entry: Wind South West by South Chromo winged out passed Cape Cod Light at 4 A.M. vessel winged out all day very fresh breeze at at 7 P.M. sighted Mt Desert Rock Light at 8 PM wind died out and baffled around Midnight the Rock Light bore South light rain squalls

Wind baffling. At 2 am wind stuck North Easterly fresh. headed North. could not fetch to windward of Duck Islands kept of went to leaward, and fetched Bass Harbor Bar. and went in Bass Harbor and anchored at 7 A.M.

Wind Easterly and rainy. Got underway at Bass Harbor at 7 AM and beat over the bar with the tide. Wind hauled Southerly stoped raining and the fog shut in anchored at Winter Harbor at 2 oclock P.M. fog very thick

Wind South West and thick with fog Went on board of the vessel at Winter Harbor and went out for Sullivan wind blowing very fresh and just before I got to Hancock Neck the job bursted. anchored at Sullivan at noon got tem and went to Franklin for a load got none came back in the evening
location: Winter Harbor, Sullivan, Hancock Neck, Franklin

journal_entry: Wind moderate Northerly Towed over the Falls to West Sullivan at G H Welsts wharf. In the afternoon went to Franklin in the yawl boat to see Mr. West. but the he being gone staid at Franklin all night

Calm in the morning At 8 AM GW West has not got home and I cannot wait longer on all account of the tide and I go back to the vessel without seeing Mr West. the wind breezing SouthWest. I start for home get a ride as far as West Gouldsboro with Peter Hil and walk home from there arriving about 8 oclock in the evening
Wind Southerly staid at home all day
Wind Southerly in the morning and hauled around Westerly At noon took the Str. Electra at Winter Harbor and went to Sullivan to join the Chromo arrived at 5 PM
Wind Westerly. Went to Franklin after a load but found nothing that suited and did not take up the offer was 35 cts per m on laiths to go to N.Y.

Cloudy in the morning and looked stormy but did not storm and the wind hauled from S.W. to N.W. At noon got as load of blocks to go to Pawtucket and New York for $260. commenced loading for J.H.West at noon. There is an understanding between Mr West and my self that if they will not take the N.y. blocks at Pawtucket I must take them to N.Y.
Wind NorthWesterly fresh Finished loading at five oclock P.M. and got bill of laden

Wind baffling from N.W to SouthWest at noon. Towed over the Falls 11 oclock A.M. and worked down the Bay. Passed through the Halibut hole at dark. and at 9 P.M. Wind South South West and raining Vessel at this time outside of Turtle Isle kept of went in by Mark Island and anchored at Winter Harbor at 10 oclock PM
location: Turtle Isle, Mark Island, Winter Harbor

journal_entry: Wind Southerly and morning and evening rainy middle of the day clear weather No chance to go out for New York. and staid at home

Wind Northerly good breeze got underway at Winter Harbor at 7.30 AM and went out for N.Y. inside Passed out by white head between sunset and dark nearly calm. In the evening the wind breezed up Northerly but moderate passed Monhegan at 11 P.M. and at midnight 2 miles past

Wind North Easterly untill noon when it hauled East then South and commenced raining hard and blowing fresh and at 3 P.M. stoped raining wind S.W. vessel heading westerly fetched in about 4 miles South of Boon Island when the wind all died out. then a very light air Northerly. at midnight Isles of Shoals bore West by North
Wind North North West at 4 A.M. brest of Thatchers Island Passed Cape Cod at 1.30 P.M. Chatham at sunset. and at midnight about halfway from the Cross Rip Light Ship to Cape Poge
location: Thatchers Island, Cape Cod, Chatham, Cross Rip Light Ship, Cape Poge

journal_entry: Wind North North West Passed Tarpaulin Cove at 4 oclock AM At 10 AM. In Block Island Channel becalmed At 11 AM wind breezed up South West. Passed the Beavertail at one P.M. and anchored at Providence just before sunset
location: Tarpaulin Cove, Block Island, Beavertail, Providence

journal_entry: Wind Northerly and quite cold. cannot tow to Pawtucket to day there are so many ahead of us and vessel have to tow by theirs turns. but at night we towed as far as the bridge to stay untill tomorrow
Wind moderate Northerly towed to Pawtucket in the forenoon and at one oclock P.M. commenced discharging stone

Wind South West. commenced work at 7 AM and worked one hour. and got all the stone out. that are comming out here. there being 3000 large N.Y. blocks they do not want them here. and I must go to N.Y. with them, as far agreement with G.H. West the shipper when I loaded at Sullivans In the afternoon the vessel towed down to Providence and I stay at Pawtucket to settle my freight then take the Cars and go down to Providence and join the vessel
Wind South South West Got underway at Providence in the morning and went down River and anchored of Wickford heavy rain in the afternoon

Wind West South West Got underway in the morning at Wickford for New York. abrest of Point Judith at noon At 2.30 PM wind N.W thence N.N.W. pass through the race at into Long Island Sound at sunset, and at midnight abrest of New Haven So ends these 24 hours
location: Wickford, New York, Point Judith, Long Island, New Haven

journal_entry: Wind North North West At 4 AM abrest of Eatons Neck and at 7 passed Throggs Point. took a tug without anchoring at Rickers Island towed through and anchored on Jersey flats at 10 oclock the Consignee being in Philadelphia telegraphed to him and got orders at 4 PM to haul in at pier one jersey City and hauled in before dark ready to discharge tomorrow
location: Eatons Neck, Throggs Point, Rickers Island, Philadelphia, Jersey City

journal_entry: Wind Northerly Went to the City of New York after a freight and took a coal order to go to South Boston for 95 cts Sent G to Gordon. Miller & Houghtons check for 40 on acct of Sch Chromo also check to Geo C Lynam for $20. one to Crabtree & Havey for 25 and one to W.M. Pitcher for $15 making $100 in all Went back to Jersey City in afternoon. got a tug boat to tow the "Chromo" to Port Johnson to load coal for Boston and when the tug took her out the dock I left and went to Newark to set Mr Shanley about selling him home stone but did not set him came back and went to Weehawker and stoped with Hugh McDandle all night
location: New York, South Boston, Jersey City, Port Johnson, Newark

journal_entry: Wind North West went from Weehawking to the City of N. York settled coal commersion tow bills & c. went back to Jersey City collected $60 of freight on stone and sold several load of paving for Mr J H. West as requested then went to Port Johnson where the vessel was but she had not began to load but had hauled in to wharf
location: Weehawken, New York, Jersey City, Port Johnson

journal_entry: Wind Northerly commenced loading In the forenoon but did not get loaded untill three oclock PM got bill of Laden and towed from the coal dock at Port Johnson to Rickers Island and anchored there at 7.30 PM with a very light air N.N.E bound to Boston

Wind North North West fresh breeze rain squalls. Got under way at Rickers Island in morning passed Execution Rock at 9 am Settled the mainsail apart way down for time halvers, then set it passed Falkners Island at 4 P.M. At dark in mainsail and double reefed it the first time for the year that any of the sails has been reefed. Passed out the Race at 8 PM at midnight abrest of Point Judith
location: Rickers Island, Execution Rock, Falkners Island, Point Judith

journal_entry: Wind North North West. Passed Vineyard Sound Light Ship at 3.30 AM Vineyard Haven at 6.30 and anchored at Edgartown at 7.30 AM. In the afternoon wind moderated and breezed up South Westerly Got underway at Edgartown at 3.30 PM. Passed the Cross Rip Light Ship at 6. Passed the Pollock Rip Light at 8.40 P.M. and at midnight Naucett Lights bore W. So ends these 24 hours

Wind South West by West fresh. Passed Cape Cod Light at 1.45 AM. wind hauled W.S.W. Arrived in Boston at noon took the tug boat and went into the wharf at South Boston below bridges. Consignes to J.P. Mullen & Co

Wind Easterly Commenced in the morning to discharge coal and all out at night. but the tide being down could not get clear from the wharf collected freight ice midnight when the tide was up the wind South West hauled away from the wharf on flats. Could not go out for the Stevedores had unshore so much of the running rigging

Wind South West by South soon as day light commenced getting ready to sail and passed Thatchers Island at 10.30 A.M. wind breezing up heavy and hauling Southerly and weather threatening And at 7 p.m. anchored at Booth bay storming and blowing a gale. bound to Sullivan

Wind moderate and baffling. at 10.30 am when the wind got fixed SouthWest. got underway at Booth bay but when the sun set we were of Musquito Island the wind came of Northerly and looked very bad and at 7 oclock PM passed into the Mussle Ridges and anchored in Lobster coal
location: Boothbay, Mosquito Island, Mussle Ridges, Lobster cove

journal_entry: Wind North North West Got underway at Lobster Cove in the mussle ridges at day light and anchored at Winter Harbor at 2 oclock P.M. the wind blowing to hard to beat up the bay against the Ebb tide
location: Losbter cove, Muscle Ridge Islands, Winter Harbor

journal_entry: Wind baffling with snow squalls and rain from north to the south by of the East. Got underway in the morning and went to West Sullivan sailing over the Falls to Mr Wests whard. Then hired a team and went home to WInter Harbor arriving at 6.30 PM
Wind Northerly. Staid at home all day the Chromo at West Sullivan

Wind Southerly harnessed the horse in the morning and went back to Sullivan then hired a team again and went to Franklin to see about a load. but finding nothing that suited we came back to West Sullivan and agreed to load random stone for New York for Crabtree & Havy for $1.25 oer net ton stone. to be weighed in Sullivan and I am to wait untill the Harvard Havy is loaded and she has not commenced yet
Wind SouthWest and rainy all day with a fresh breeze. The Harvard Havy did not commence to load to day on account of the rain. therefore I shall not get loaded this week
Wind Northerly and fine My bitrh day 39 years. commenced painting vessel inside of waist. while waiting for the Harvard Havey to load

Wind South East and a little snowy in the forenoon. Unbent the Chromos mainsail carried it across the River to Hancock hauled it to the depot put on in the cars and went to Ellsworth to put the sail in the sail lift for repairs. went in the 2.15 PM train and came back on the 8.45 train to Hancock
Wind Easterly and light snow very moderate. Commenced loading at noon with random Stone for New York. for Crabtree & Havey took in about 25 tons
Wind South Easterly and snowy began work in the morning and it snowed so hard quit work at 9 A.M. Then got Capt. Van Gordons team and went home to stay untill Presidential Election

Wind NorthWest fresh. In the afternoon took the team that I came home with Saturday from Sullivan and went to the Marsh with my wife and came home in the evening. the wind had gone down so it was quite pleasant
Wind NorthWest and moderate. work about home all day. and shiped Geo pendleton to go to N.Y. with me

Wind South West bought a gun of John Fross at 11 oclock AM started for West Sullivan with Geo Pendletons Baggage Stoped at West Gouldsboro at the town house and voted for Presidential Electors then went to the Chromo at West Sullivan and find her loaded. arriving at 3 P.M. at 7 raining hard Went to Blakes Hall to see them dance for one hour

Wind Southerly in morning and a very heavy rain filled water got bill of laden and towed over the Falls and anchored. Rain held up wind hauled Westerly and cleared up. Went ashore to the blacksmith and had the anchor stoped mended. ice.
Wind from West to West North West. blowing a gale all day bent mainsail lying at Sullivan below the falls. In the afternoon let go the second anchor no chance to get out

Wind from West by N. to West NorthWest. blowing a gale, all forenoon. when it began to moderate. Got underway and went out for New York. When abrest of lower part of Iron Bormel Island, took the wind West South West and beat to South West Harbor anchored a little after dark
Wind North West. blowing fresh. Got underway at SouthWest Harbor in morning and went to Froy Island at 3 PM wind blowing to hard to go any further, and let go the Second anchor to fetch her up
Wind Northerly Got underway at Froy Island at day light. At noon abrest of white head becalmed. then the wind breezed up South West. beat to Port Clyde and anchored at sun set
Wind West South West Lay at anchor all day at Port Clyde. could not get out as the wind blew in and other vessels blocked the harbor
Wind SouthWest lay at anchor all day at Port Clyde Went on shore to get a paper to find out how the Presidential Election went. but got nothing that is satisfactory

Wind North West Got underway at Port Clyde at sunrise. Passed Seguin at 11 AM wind hauling northerly and in the afternoon Easterly thence South very moderate. At sunset Boom Island bore West. At midnight Thatchers Island Light could be seen from a loft bearing South West.
location: Port Clyde, Seguin, Boom Island, Thatchers Island

journal_entry: Wind South West. At 6 oclock in the morning Thatchers Island bore North West about 6 miles distant. Kept the vesselheading Southerly for Cape Cod. At noon the wind breezed up. At 2 oclock P.M. took in all light sails. and at 6 oclock PM close into Cape Cod. At Eleven oclock anchored East South East from Chatham P.M.
Wind NorthWest got underway at Chatham in the morning wind breezed up fresh and hauled more Westerly. At sunset anchored at Edgartown

Wind NorthWest Got underway at 10 am when the tide turned at Edgartown. Got abrest of West Chop and the wind died out. And the tide took the vessel passed Tarpaulin Cove. and when the head tide made the wind aired up South Easterly and we went out the Vineyard Sound
location: Edgartown, West Chop, Tarpaulin Cove, Vineyard Sound

journal_entry: Wind very light Easterly Passed Vineyard Sound Light Ship at one am Block Island at 12 m and the Race at 6 PM midnight abrest of the Middle Ground between Stratford & Old Field. So ends these 24 hours
location: Vineyard Sound Lightship, Block Island, Stratford, Old Field

journal_entry: Wind moderate. North Easterly in the morning. At 8 am brest of Eatons Neck wind died out calm and calm untill 4 PM. when the wind breezed up Northerly anchored at City Island at 8 oclock P.M.
Wind North North East. Got underway at City Island in the morning and went to Rickers Island anchored took tug boat and towed through the gate to our berth at 44th ST N.R.
Wind North Easterly snow, and rain all day did nothing toward discharging vessel
Wind westerly but not clear weather did nothing toward discharging as the takle fall was wet and would not work
Wind SouthWest and fine weather commenced unloading in the morning. at night half discharged
Wind Southerly and moderate finished discharging at 4 PM and in the evening hauled into the River

Wind Southerly. Got underway in the NorthRiver at day light for Pert Amboy beat the whole flood tide in the Narrows In the afternoon the wind blowed very heavy and anchored at Port Amboy at 4 PM evening blowing a gale and rainy in torrents. at 8 PM let go another anchor

Wind blowing heavy west north west took cars in forenoon and went to new yotk from perth amboy to settle freight on stone and settle bills that could not be paid untill & got my freight money afte settling my freight took Ferry bot at N.Y. and went to Statten Island then took cars to Perth Amboy crossing from Staten Island to Amboy in ferry boat on arriving found the Chromo hauled into the wharf
location: Perth Amboy, Staten Island, New York

journal_entry: Wind SouthWest Commenced loading coal at Perth Amboy for Sullivan for C. Emery & Son. freight 90 cts per ton & discharged. At night not quite loaded
WInd West North West Finished loading coal at Perth Amboy at noon Towed out the dock made sail and went out. And at 6 PM anchored at Red Hook

Wind SouthWest Towed through the Gates when the tide turned and was through about on P.M. and made sail then the wind very light. And at sun set about down to Execution Rocks. and took the wind Easterly and went back to City Island and anchored
Wind Easterly moderate raining all the time after 10 oclock A.M. Laying at anchor all day at City Island bound to Sullivan

Wind North North West fresh breeze. At 9 oclock A.M. double reefed the mainsail and got underway. Passed Falkners Island at 4 PM Passed through the Race at 9.30 P.M. and at midnight Block Island light bore South East by Point Judith light just coming in light
location: Falkners Island, Block Island, Point Judith

journal_entry: Wind Northerly. Passed Vineyard Sound Light Ship at 5 am Tarpaulin Cove at 9 AM West Chop at 10.30 AM wind died out the tide ahead. and did not get back to West Chop untill 4 oclock P.M. when a very light air of wind North Easterly anchored at Edgartown at 7.30 P.M.
location: Vineyard Sound, Tarpaulin Cove, West Chop, Edgartown

journal_entry: Wind Northerly Lay at anchor all day at Edgartown No chance to get around the Cape

Wind North North East Chromo lay at anchor all day at Edgartown Capt H E Tracy of the Schr Halmar and very self went gunning in Cape Poge Pond got two White wing coots In the evening went a shore at Edgartown to hear some hubilee singers at the Hall

Wind North East fresh all day. Lay at anchor all day at Edgartown In evening Capt H E Tracy and myself with an invitation from some friends went on shore to visit the Pickwick Club and of which we employed ourselves the shole evening

Wind Westerly Got underway at Edgartown at 6 oclock AM. passed Cross Rip Light Ship at 12.30 PM. Naucetts at sun set Old Cape Cod 6.20 PM And at midnight just passed Thatchers Island lights, wind W.S.W strong. So ends these 24 hours
location: Edgartown, Cross Rip Light Ship, Naucett, Old Cape Cod, Thatchers Island

journal_entry: Wind moderate Westerly untill noon when it remained calm untill midnight was abrest of Boon Island at 4 AM. and at noon was nearly abrest of Seguin and remained statting there untill midnight when a light air of wind is breezing up Easterly

Wind East by South and overcast and partially foggy. vessel by the wind heading North Easterly At 5 oclock AM close in to Pemmaquid Point At 8 AM abrest of Monhegan. and at dark anchored at Owls Head Harbor

Wind South in the morning and very heavy rain At eleven oclock AM cleared up wind W.W.W Got underway at Owls Head. and sunset anchored at Cranberry Isles dare not run for Sullivan on account of the darkness

Wind Westerly fresh breeze, Got under way at Cranberry Isles at 5 oclock AM and went to Sullivan and anchored at 8 oclock P.M. At dark on the high water towed over the falls to discharge Mr Murphy Mare and Geo. Pendleton hand refused to take the wages agreed up on as they signed no articles and the amount of there wages was deposited with Geo C. Lynan after rendering then it and they refusing to accept it
Wind North West & moderate. Stevedores begin to discharge coal in the morning. At noon I got Capt. Van B. Gordons and went home after setting my freight on coal at 90 cts per ton and discharged

Wind North West and very fresh breeze and cold At one oclock P.M. started for Sullivan with my wife arriving at 3.30 P.M. completely chilled with the cold. The Chromo only partialy discharged will go below the falls to finish onloading

About calm in the morning towed down over the Falls in the morning with the intention of going into the wharf at Sullivan but there not being tide enough could not get there. Wind breezed up Easterly and a moderate snow storm all day Not tide enough at night to get in to the wharf only the bow of the vessel. Geo Pendleton goes a George Lynam and gets his money I deposited
About calm all day. The Stevedores work all day discharging coal Ice making fast

Wind Northerly and very cold At 4 oclock PM the vessel was discharged when Chromo floated at 7 P.M. commenced getting her of from the wharf by beaking ice and running kedge anchor. Got her of to an anchor at 11 oclock PM Thermometer at zero
Very moderate wind North Wst and cold. Two of us got the Chromo underway and went to Winter Harbor and went along side of the Steam boat wharf to haul up for the winter
Wind South. heavy breeze and big rain storm built coal bin at home
Wind Westerly fresh took my bid clothes out of the vessel
Wind North West and snowing all day
Wind Northerly work most all day getting coal out of Chromo and hauling some home
Wind North North West and the thermometer at zero all day. Did nothing in particular on board the vessel as it was to cold
Wind N.N.W. Thermometer 14 degrees below zero to cold to work out of door

Wind Northerly in morning and the thermometer 8 degrees below and snowing hard. at 10 AM wind hauled out South Easterly and the Thermometer went to 32 degreesabove in the evening heavy rain and blow. Chromo along the Steam boat wharf
Wind South South West and moderate. Took the remainder of my coal out of vessel and put it on the wharf. ready to haul hoome when it freezes
Wind Westerly and quite warm ground to soft to haul coal
Wind North West and cold. Finished hauling my coal home from the Steam boat wharf
Christmas day wind North West. Staid about home
Wind Northerly Work about home all day on various kinds of work

Wind very light North Easterly. In forenoon run an anchor out astern of Chromo to hold her from going ahead. In the afternoon delivered up a Safe that has been in the housr for years belonging to the heirs of the late Josheph More by under of said heirs to Robert Milliken
Wind Southerly light and moderate rain A little snow on the ground fast melting
Calm all day doing nothing in particular but jogging about home
Wind very moderate Southwest. Work in forenoon on bound of Schr Chromo getting down more fenders also getting out chains to make fast with instead of hawsers

Wind SouthWest. and moderate and warm no snow only in little places on the ground. Took dora. and went gunning in forenoon but found no gang. The Chromo That I have been sailing for two years is hauled up the 14th Dec Subscribed for the Boston Daily Journal. Living at Mrs Jemie Kingsleys house instead of our own left our own the 16th of January at the death of Mr. J. F. Kingsley

Wind moderate Southerly Indications of a storm snow squalls. The Sch. Chromo hauled up for the winter at the Steam boat wharf. I live at Ms Kingsleys house. Moved over at the death of Joseph Kingsleys which occures the 16th day of January 1884. I have been Master of the Sch Chromo a little more than two years. The ground entirely free from snow.
Wind North NorthWest the Thermometer down to zero most all day. Work most all day repairing a Barbers chair for James Westcott.
Wind Westerly Thermometer 14 degrees above. Work about home all day
Wind Northerly in forenoon and SouthWest in after noon Thermometer about 34 degree abovezero.
Wind Southerly fresh. Work about home all day. In the evening Went to a meeting of the Stock holders of Pacific Hall and acted as Clerk acting by power of Atty. not being a stock holder
Wind Southerly and at 9 AM began torain and rained all day. Wrote deed from Carrie G Mathews to Wm H Sargent and one from Wm H  Sargent to George Mathews.
Wind SouthWest and thick with fog. Bought two Bbls apples got them home.
Wind Westerly fresh. Work in shop on windows putting in glass all day
Wind Southerly Work for Capt J R Hammond in Shop making Organ Stool
Wind SouthWest blowing a gale Work in Shop on small jobs. Made skate woods for Frank Tracy.
Wind Southerly afternoon fresh and evening stormy. The ground as bare from snow as in the summer non to be seen in any direction
Wind Southerly and blowing a gale with heavy rain
Wind NorthWest Thermometer about 30 degrees above all day. Work for Jannie Kingsley shingling the hen house

Wind Northerly in forenoon. Went to the Lower Harbor after a stick to make a flying jib boom for the Sch. A.G.Brooks back at noon and in the afternoon the Wind SouthWest. Ground entirly free from snow

Wind Easterly Commenced to run land on our back lot that was bought of Wm Handy. But it commenced to snow and come out the woods at 10 oclock A.M. In the afternoon commenced to make a part of a Suveyors compass.
Wind NorthEasterly Afternoon snowy Commenced making a flying jib boom for Sch A.G. Brooks
Wind Easterly and in the forenoon rainy. Afternoon wind Southerly and at night wind Westerly Not being very well did not work, anywhere.
Wind Westerly did not go out of door not being well
Wind West NorthWest Feeling quite well Helped J R Hammond and Roderic  Pendleton run a line between Roderic Pendletons Western bound on his back lot and our own
Wind NorthWest Work most all day for J.H. Smallrdge on flying jibboom
Wind Westerly Finished boom for A.G.Brooks
Wind NorthWest. and blowing a gale Thermometer 4 degrees below zero and at 9 P.M. 8 below 0 Made a sled roller for John Foss.
Wind Thermometer 4 degrees. below zero in the morning but it soon moderated work in shop.
Wind Easterly and snowing hard all day. In the forenoon on board the Chromo at work, and in the afternoon worked in shop at home
Wind Southerly quite moderate.

Calm or nearly so all day. Worke in the forenoon on board of the Chromo on penders. In the afternoon went to Milbridge to a Masonie Meeting to be held in the evening the Lodge opened on the third degree. one man Bro book was raised from the degree of Fellow Craft to the subline of a M.Mason Midnight started for home.

Wind NorthWest and growing cold. Arrived home from Milbridge at 2.30 in the morning where I had been to attend a Masonic Meeting. Work all day getting ready to start a Masonic Lodge of instructions at Winter Harbor.

Wind NorthNorthEast Thermometer 10 degrees below zero and snowing all day Island at home and studied hard all day preparing myself for a Lodge of Instructions. Masons meet tonight but I am unable to attend having a bad cold.
Wind NorthWest. fresh breeze and cold. Was notified that the masons met at the hall last evening and Elected me Master of the Lodge.
Wind SouthWest Staid about home. making working tools for the Lodge.
Wind Westerly and quite moderate work at home repairing doors etc.
Wind South East. and thick with snow. all day.
Wind NorthWest. blowing a gale with the Thermometer down to zero.
West NorthWest. Thermometer 5 degrees above zero. Work about home jobbing
Wind NorthEast. In the evening went to the hall to a Masonic Lodge Myself Master In the evening snowing
Wind NorthEast work abou home
Wind Northerly Studying to post myself in Masonery in the forenoon. and in the after noon work in shop on Surveyors Compass. that I had begun to make some time ago and nearly completed it.
Wind Southerly and fresh blustering
Wind NorthWest. Thermometer 20 degree above zero.
Wind NorthWest in forenoon and Calm in afternoon Work in shop making picture frame and mending chairs. In evening went to Singing school. at 9 PM wind Easterly.
Wind East South East and a gale with terrific rain all day
Wind SouthWest Sold one halfton hay to J J Roberts In the evening went to the Masonic meeting at the Hall
Wind NorthWest about home all day not engaged in any particular business.
Wind North NorthWest about home all day
Wind NorthEast and fine weather work in shop turning troll roller for R.M. Trorry and some posts for Wm Fernalds vessels quarter sail.
Wind North North East In the morning a little snowy the remainder of the day pleasant.
Wind Easterly and increased to a gale Went to Millredge
NA
NA
Wind NorthWest Went to a religious meeting at the Hall
Wind from West to West SouthWest built sheeprack in the Barn for Jennie Kingsley In evening went to Singing School
Wind NorthWest Not buisy in any thing in particular
Very light air NorthWest in the forenoon. The sleighing good as can be.
Wind NorthWest Turned stairpost for Winslow Joy.
Wind NorthWest and moderate having fire wood hauled.
Wind Moderate and very warm. recd company all the forenoon. and in the after noon went to a town caucus at the Hall and in the evening went to the Masonic Lodge.

Calm in forenoon Went to Franklin with N.A.Bickford and with J S Surgents horse to see about a load for the Chromo when the ice is out came home in the after noon Wind SouthWest stoped to tea and the evening with my wipe at Capt A J Gerrish and Wipes
local_place: Home, Franklin village, Home, A. J. Gerrish's, Home

journal_entry: Moderate Easterly wind fair weather About home all day cutting wood at the door. The Singing school closed to day.
Wind Northerly in forenoon SouthWest in afternoon but wood in forenoon at the door and in the afternoon wrote deed from Ira B Zross to Roderic Pendleton
Wind Southerly snowy in morning and rainy in the afternoon Lent Loring Rand $6.00 for fefteen days.
Wind Southerly and raining hard in the morning at 8 AM cleared up and went to Town meeting and Elected Town Officers.
notes: I assumed that town meeting was at Hall, but needs to be checked

journal_entry: Wind NorthWesterly fine and moderate work in shop in the forenoon and in the afternoon got shingle the front side of the sorf of our old house The shingles bough of Capt J R Hammond
Wind SouthEasterly and apart ofthe day snowy. Work all day in the shop putting ladder together for G.W.Tracy filing saws and cutting wood In evening went to Masonic meeting at the Hall
Calm all day work in shop turning stair posts and balusters for Winslow Joy In the Evening went to a Masquerade ball at the Hall
Wind North West and moderate. Recd company all day from Franklin and other places. did not work in shop

Wind East North East Went on Grindstone point with Nicholas Bunker hunting foxes with a hound got none. In the afternoon helped Mr Farrows of Rockland take the Mlasure of the Sch Chromo for a suit of sails at the wharf Winter Harbor.
Wind NorthEast. very light snow in the morning Went to West Bay with J D Harrington. kors to carry Wm Farrowth Sailmaker of Rockland hsce Wm Fernald and Sherman Spurling came back in the afternoon
Wind Northerly. Turned a stair post for my self for a sample. In the evening was door keeper at Prof. C. O. Nortons Exhibition at the Hall. Winter Harbor.

Wind NorthWest and quite blustering. Finished turning polls for Wm Fernalds vessel In the evening went to South Goulsboro to Prof. C. O. Nortons Exhibition accompanied by my family and Roderic Pendleton and wife
Wind NorthWest. Thermometer from 12 to 20 degree above 0 working at the stocking of a gun for C. J. Bunker. In the evening went to Masonic Lodge at the Hall.
Win North East. and snowy. The Thermometer at 7 a.m. down to zero. Work most all day on gun stock for CJBunker

In the morning the Thermometer 7 degrees blow zero. light air of wind NorthWest. Finished stocking gun for CJBunker in forenoon. In the afternoon went to Listrict muting at the School house and chosen moderator.
Wind North East and light snow in the morning. Made fenders in the shop for Chromo The Sleighing as good as at any time during the winter
Wind East North East and pleasant in the morning but in the evening began to snow and rain hard.
Wind South Easterly and stormy At 9 AM cleared up wind Northerly. The snow has settled lots since yesterday  Got Organ home for Stella from Mrs Fannie Bickford Work about home.
Wind NorthWest Work in forenoon cutting wood at the door. In the afternoon work in the shop turning on lathe and jobbing

Calm in the morning Thermometer down to zero. Work in forenoon cutting wood at the door. afternoon in the Shop. In the evening went to the Masonic Lodge and closed it for the season wind Easterly and at 10 PM snowing
Wind NorthEast. Fresh breeze and snowing hard. afternoon wind hauled Northerly and blustering
Wind W.N. West. and cold. work cutting wood at the door in forenoon
Wind Westerly blowing fresh and at sunrise The Thermometer down to zero making it too blustering to work out of door
Wind Westerly and moderate.
Wind North East in morning and hauled Northerly. Finished cutting my wood at the door. and shoveled snow of Chromos deck
Wind W. N. W. in the morning and SouthWest in the afternoon. work on board of the Chromo getting the ice of deck.
Wind South West in forenoon. Work on board the Chromo. In the afternoon the wind wind hauled around Westerly with snow squalls. Helped Ms Jennie Kingsley at the Choping bee cutting wood at the door.
Calm in morning Wind SouthWest at 10 AM until night work board the Cromo all day. getting ready to go to loading
Wind South SouthWest work on board the Chromo in forenoon, and in the afternoon work for James AStevens huved and eight squared a stick to make a main boom for the Schr Grace and Steven's

Calm in the morning Took the Sch Chromo from her mooring at the wharf by getting both anchor Washed the vessel down both out side and on deck in forenoon and in afternoon painted the Starboard side and droped along side Orozimbo
Wind North East and forenoon snowy. At night wind went down
Wind Easterly and hauled South Finished painting the "Chromo", and got provisions on board getting ready  to sail.
Wind Southerly and blowing fresh and looking all day as though at was going to storm. Work all day in shop making fenders and getting ready to go away. At night put my bedding on board.
Wind Southerly filled water and got every thing on board ready to Sail.

Wind North West. in morning. Got ubderway and and went out for West Sullivan. At noon becalmed of Troun Bound Head. In afternoon wind breezed up Southerly got to Sullivan at 2' oclock P.M. but not time enough to get over the Falls and anchored below
Light air of wind Easterly and thick with fog The book cane one of board.   When the tide got up there was not wind enough to get over the Falls
Wind Easterly fresh breeze Thick with fog and rainy Got underway and went over the falls at 11 AM alongside of J. HWests wharf
Wind Northerly and snow squalls in morning but at noon thewind Westerly and very pleasant.

Heavy rain before daylight with the wind Southerly In forenoon cleared up wind hauling Westerly. Commenced loading Chromo with edge stone for Philadelphia loading for J H West at West Sullivan. In afternoon the wind NorthWest with rain squalls. $132.50 due Veazie National Bank of Bangor in 60 days
Wind light and baffling from NorthWest to South West. Work all day loading the Chromo with edgedtone.
Wind South and heavyrain did not work loading on account of the rain

Wind N.N. West. and a very heavy breeze. Finished loading the Chromo with stone Cargo consists of 20.086 feet of 6 in edge stone 14 corner pieces and one piece of random of abt 5 tons. Got a check for $130 of J.HWest on the Veazie Nation Bank Bangor

Calm in morning At 8 oclock AM took tug boat and turned over the Falls and anchored. Took from the freight house a Mainsail for the Chromo made in Rockland and sent down the boat Wind breezed up S.W. Got underway at 5 oclock PM anchored at Winter Harbor.
Calm in morning At 9 AM wind breezed up SouthWest. Got under way at Winter Harbor at 9 AM and went out At Sunset anchored at North East Harbor about calm. went ashore vistling

Calm untill 9 AM wind breezed up moderate S.S. West. Got underway at North East Harbor. and beat through the Western way over the bar and anchored at the Eastern entrance of York Narrows at 5 oclock PM the tide ahead to get through.

Wind EastNorthEast. and rainy. Got the Mussle Ridge at noon and got becalmed then took a light air of wind SouthWest. Then at 2.30 PM took alight air South East. anchored at Port Clyde at 6 oclock P.M.

Wind North North West. Got underway at Port Clyde at day light At 10.30 AM passed Seguin on the Starboard brand. At 8 oclock PM passed Boon Island on the starboard bow about 8 miles distant. At 10.40 Thatchers Island bore West. Midnight good breeze North West by North. So ends these 24 hours.

Wind North West. At 4 oclock AM abrest of the old Cape Light. At 8 A.M hove to near the Pallock Rip waiting for the tide to turn Westerly. At 10 am the tide turned and we went on Shoals. Wind hauled Westerly and began to blow. At 11 am carried away the foretopivast. which took away the crosstrees when it fell. no serious danger done to the sails. When hallway from the H and Kerchiy Light Ship it was agale. Kept of and went to Hyannis anchored at 3.30 in the afternoon.

Wind North NorthWest and moderate. Got underway at Hyainns at 9 oclock A.M. which is as soon as there was wind enough to stern the tide then the wind was very baffling from every point of the Compass. At one oclock PM the wind breezed up W.S.W. in earnest. Went into Tarpaulin boree and anchored at 4 P.M. went on shore filled water Mailed letters etc.

Wind North NorthWest. on account of vessels laying out side of us we have to wait for them to get underway first. Which being it at 4 oclock or nearly daylight before we can get under way at Tarpaulin boree. At noon becalmed of Block Island. In the afternoon the wind breezed up South West. At 5 PM close in to the buoy of Montauk Point. At 10 PM becalmed about 5 or 6 miles S. W. from Montauk Point when a very light wind at ame from the North a little more than enough to keep from going ashore with the sea. At midnight had worked of shore a little wind very moderate so ends these 24 hours.

Wind Northerly and very light. No land in light when came morning. Wind hauled Easterly. At Noon I at 40.26. Afternoon wind hauled South East. Then has not averaged more than from 4 to 5 knots per horn during the entire 24 hours. Thus ends these 24 hours without seemd land Shinercook was lost to view.

Wind very moderate North Easterly thence South Easterly and calm At 8 oclock AM sighted Barnegat Light House directly ahead which had been looked for all night but for which was so moderate made no headway At 4 oclock PM we had got a little past Barnegat by being hovering ahead by the sea at dark perfectly calm At midnight light Westerly and Barnegat beares North and Absecum bears West so ends these 24 hours

Very light wind N.W. with a land fog hanging around which soon cleared away. At noon Abzeems bore North about 10 miles distant Wind Southerly At 6 PM close in to the North East End of the five fathom bank Light Ship At 8 PM Cape May bore N.W.N. and Cape Henlopen W.S.W. The tide being ahead we make slow progress by not having the use of the outer jib and for topsail the fore topmast being carried away on Nuntuckel Sloals Midnight not much further along than at 8 PM.

Wind South West. At 4 AM close in to Cape Henlopen When up to Grass Ledge becalmed. In the afternoon a very moderate wind South E. At 8 oclock in the after noon anchored between Reecly Island and Fort Delaware.

Calm in the morning got underway at daylight but could not keep the vessel in the Channel and anchored again At one oclock PM it was still calm and being anxious to get to West Philadelphia took a tug boat from where we lay below Fort Delaware and towed up the Schuylkill to West Philadelphia arriving at the wharf at 6.30 P.M. This day has been a dead calm untill 4 PM when a light air S.E.
Wind Easterly Lay at the wharf at West Philadelphia In the afternoon took a pen stone of deck
Wind N.N. East Chromo lying in the Schuylkill River on West Philadelphia side. discharging cargo all day.

Wind blows up the Schuylkill and suppose it to be North Easterly The Chromo discharged at 3 oclock PM and settled for my freight money $285. and discharged. according to be bill of Lading. Got coal order to go to Kennebunk Port freight $125 and discharged Jemploy no Broker. but do my own work.
Wind Easterly and rainy Chromo discharged But still laying at Schuylkill

Wind South West. Took tug boat at the Schuylkill and towed out and up to Port Richmond to Pier 14 to load coal. Sent Mitter and Houghton P.O. order $10.50 on last years acct. Sent Win R Farrow of Rockland $30. on acct. of Sch Chromo mainsail Chromo loaded to day and ready to go down river at 6.30 P.M.

Wind South Easterly Took tug boat in the morning and towed down River from Philadelphia to Chester then worked down River undersail to Reedy Island anchoring at 6 P.M During the whole afternoon tremendous thunder and lightning and heavy rain. apart of the day nearly calm then the wind would be fresh At 10 oclock PM the wind came North West and blew a heavy gale. The new mainsail was towing down from Rhilada to Chester.
Wind North West and blowing a heavy gale Vessel laying to an anchor at Reedy Island. Bound to Kennebunk Port me with 202 tons coal At night wind moderated.

Wind moderate N.W. Got under way at Reedy Island two oclock A.M passed Ship John shoal at 5 A.M. 14 ft bank Light Ship one on N E 5 facthour Bank bore South East. At midnight wind SouthWest and overcast Absecum light bore West North West

Wind baffling and moderate rain and very overcast Wind at times EN.E. and E.S. East Got sight of Barnegat Light at 4 AM bearing N.N.W. At noon the wind breezed up and grew thick And at 4 PM finding we could not reach Sandy Hook on account of scant wind and rough tacked ship and run of for one hour so to have a plenty of sea ruom for a breeze. At 5 PM took in light sails and purled then and double reefed the mainsail. Wind increasing about N.E. At midnight took in the jib vessel hovering to a very heavy sea running so ends these 24 hours

Wind North and rainy with a tremendous chop and high sea running At 8 AM fudged our silver about 50 miles South East from Sandy Hook. At 10 AM broke the outer jib boom of in a sea while hovering two Then hauled the vessel around and headed westerly. Rigged the outer jibbom in that was hanging in the water at noon moderated and at 3 P.M. wind W.S.W. Shook reef out mainsail and set jib. At 4 PM was spake bya Pilat bat who sail Barnegat bore WNW about 25 miles. At that time the wind N. W Midnight same so ends these 24 hours.

Wind NortgWest good breeze. and hauled around West At noon sighted Schinnecook 32 miles West from Montauk In the afternoon wind hauled SouthWest. At 7 PM becalmed Montauk Light bearing N.N.E about 5 miles distant So ends these 24 hours

Calm untill day light when a light air of wind came from NorthEast Our position about the same as last night. it being calm all the time. At one oclock P.M. close in to Block Island leaving it on starboard hand. At 2 PM it commenced raining At dark was between Point Judith and the Bevertail becalmed and troped kedge anchor to keep from drifting ashore. It had been my intention to get into Dutch Island Harbor. but on account of head tide and calm could not. At midnight light air Northerly got kedge and filled away

At 2 oclock AM becalmed about 5 miles East of Brentons Reef Light ship. At 10 AM breezed up moderate S.S.W. Passed by Jarpaulin Cove at 4 P.M. Wind hauled South Anchored at Vineyard Haven at sunset. very overcast and looking all the time like rain

Wind East South East and looking all the time like a storm. lay at anchor all day at Vineyard Haven. Tried to get sticks topmast and flying jibboom but could not. Thave  found a piece of oak timber to make crossties gl when it gets smooth

Wind East fresh Got underway at 11 AM at Vineyard Haven when the tied turned to rim East and went to Edgartown where it was smooth about working aloft. the fore cross tries being broken by the fall of the fore top mast I have decided to repair damages so far as I can before going home. fuooding the wind holds it the Eastward
Wind Easterly and at night rainy. Made for crosstrees. and put them up in place of the broken. Lay at anchor all day at Edgartown.
Wind Easterly and afternoon rainy lay at anchor all day at Edgartown

Wind South West. Got underway at Edgartown at 5 A.M. Came of the Shauls at noon. Passed Cape Cod Light house at 4 P.M. At 8 - oclock becalmed about halfway from Cape Cod Light House to Thatches Island Lights at the same time So ends these 24 hours

Wind light from North West to South West and baffling At 4 AM Thatche Island Cve West by N At noon close in to Boon Island. At 2.30 P.M took Pilot from a fishing Schooner. Who was in apart fishing and looking for us. And anchored at the mouth of the tide being down could not get in
Wind SouthWest. At 9 AM got under way at the mouth of the Kennebunk Rain and with the boat ahead sailed to Kennebunkport And in the afternoon commenced discharging coal.

Wind South West. Work in forenoon discharging coal. Did not work in afternoon as the vessel had to be moved to another wharf. It being another kind of coal. In the afternoon I found a stick to make a flying jibboom and commenced making it with the help of another man

Wind North East. Stevedors work on the coal discharging and I working on flying jibboom The coal out at 4.30 P.M. This afternoon it has rained most all the time and I have only worked 6.5 hours on boom to day but with the help on a man we have got it light squared Settled up for freight at 5 P.M. freight money amounting to $252.50 there being 202 tons at $1.25 and discharged Cost of Pilotage in Kennebunk Port $10.00 one and all or per oral

Wind Northerly and pleasant. Worked on flying jibboom untill 11 AM and took it on board and the Pilot takes charge maker sail and casts of. When we got to the mouth of the River took wind South And by runing lines got out clear. heavy sea runing. At dark wind West Seguin bore N.N.E. Midnight Wind N..E. Pilot fees out $300 Making $13.00 in and out.

Wind North East by East. and light. Beat untill 4 oclock PM when we wire close into the can buoy off the Old man South from Georges Island. when the wind went Southerly and hauledto to go out side At midnight about halfway from Monhegan to Matinicus Rock light.

Nearly calm or quite so At 6 oclock AM was about in the same position as at midnight with a heavy sea from the Eastward. The wind began to breeze up and at 8 A.M. finding we could not get outside of Matinicus Rock went inside At one oclock P.M. abreast of Isle au Haut at 5 P.M. abreast of Long Island. at 8 PM passed the duck Island. at Midnight about half way from Bakes Island to Schoodic So ends these 24 hours.

Calm. but the tide and sea worked the vessel ahead and passed Mark Island at 2 oclock A.M. and anchored at Winter Harbor at Sunrise. In the afternoon took Pians ahore that I bought in Philadelphia At night heavy rain
Wind Southerly. Took oval out of Chromo that was left on board by the Stevedover in Kennebunk

Wind Northerly Got underway at Winter Harbor in the morning and Went out for Sullivan  At 3 oclock PM Just as got to the anchoring place at Sullivan. We took the Wind SouthWest Went over the Falls and into the wharf
Wind very light North in Morning. S.W. in afternoon. Commenced loading Random and Block paving to go to Philada for J.H.West. Freight $300. by the lump sun

Wind SouthWest Went to Franklin in boat after a stick to make a fore topmast. got at. and towed it down to West Sullivan and took it on the wharf where it would be a chance to make it arriving at noon. And at night the Chromo was loaded and hauled out to let the Sch Geo. W Collins in to thewharf

Wind Southerly Chromo at West Sullivan loaded bound to Philadelphia but did not go out an account of not having bills ofladen Mr West being gone And I wanted to make a fore topmast which I did and had it nearly done at night and took it on board.

Wind Southerly and thick with fog Took tug boat. at 8 AM and towed over the Falls. Made sail and beat down the bay sometimes the fog woved light enought so could see across the bay. Anchored at Winter Harbor at 4 oclock P.M
Wind Southerly thick with fog and drizzling rain. Work apart of the day onboard of the Chromo untill it rained so hard I had to leave.

Wind Southerly work all day on board of the Chromo at Winter Harbor sent up fore topmast and rigged out flying jibboom Sent checks and money to J.H. West to take up note which falls due the 6 day of apr.
Wind Southerly work on board of the Chromo. all day setting up rigging vessel lying in the Sand Cove Winter Harbor. At 4 P.M. the wind Northerly for a fur minutes and rain then back Southerly

Wind Northerly in morning W. had about two hours work to do in the moring ruving of haliards and getting ready to sail Got underway at 9 AM And when we got to the end of Grindstone Point took the wind S.W. At sunset off Long Island Head. Wind hauled Westerly At midnight a little past Isle au haut fine Weather.

Wind Westerly At 3 AM Matinicus Rock Light bore N.W. and the wind hauled South West. At noon judging ourselves 30 miles South of Matinicus Rock hue taked ship and healed W by N at 4 PM took in outer jib and foretopsail judging the vessel to be going about 5 knots sharp up. to the wind  Midnight Cape Elizabeth Lights bore N.N.E. Cape Porpoise light bore N.W. by W. quite choppy but good weather. So ends these 24 hours.

Wind SouthWest and hauled South afternoon rainy. Sighted Cape Ann at 2 P.M. bearing W. by S kept of and run for Eastern Point and was off the Point at dark becalmed at 11 oclock PM wind breezed up SouthEast Went into Gloucester anchored at midnight
Wind Easterly and very thick with fog and rain. Vessel lying in Gloucester bound to Philad with Stone for J.H. West

Wind North East. For underway in the morning at Gloucester and went out the sea running sharp. at noon becalmed. In the afternoon wind breezed up a little. South East At 6 PM thick with fog. At 8.30 P.M. A squall from the North took in all sail except foresail Wind went Easterly and kept thick. At midnight wind hauled West and cleared up. Made all sail. Cape Cod bearing North 5 miles dis

Wind Westerly Went on the shoals at 7 A.M. Wind hauled NorthWest. Passed Farpaulin Cove at 9 oclock PM with the wind North fresh and the weather looking like a heavy Easterly We have a shang head tide through the Vineyard Sound from West Chop Passed Vineyard Sound Light Ship at 11.30 P.M. Wind Moderating. Vessel running West for the North of Block Island as on account of the weather looking so bad I am undesided which way to go of Long Island

Wind Northerly and hauling Easterly Passed by the North Point of Block Island at 7 AM And Montauk Point at 11 AM and at 2 oclock PM Wind S. and gradually hauling. At midnight Shunnicoock Light bore North Wind South West So ends these 24 hours.

Wind South West and hauled out South and partially overcast. and very moderate. At noon Sighted. Fire Island At 3 PM thick with fog. At at 6 PM fog lighted and was close in to the Whislling buoy of Fire Island. At 9 oclock PM wind breezed string with lightning the weather looking wild took in all light sails and double reefed the mainsail At midnight very sharp sea running So ends these 24 hours.

Wind SouthWest fresh At 8 AM shoak the reef out mainsail and set flying jib and headed Westerly At 2 PM made the High lands of Neversink ahead Then took the wind N.W and S.W. with sain thunder and lightning At 6 P.M. When close in to Sandy Hook Light Ship took a heavy squall N.N.E Hauled down all sail. and set a twi reefed foresail and keped of before the wind. At midnight Barnegat bore W.S.W wins moderating. Shook reefed put foresail set jib and double reefed mainsail

Wind N.N.E high sea wind moderating abreast of Barnegat at 1 oclock AM at 4 AM set all sail Passed Absecum at 9 AM At noon wind southerly. At sunset Cape May bore W.S.W and Hereford Inlet N.W. At midnight Cape May bore N.N.W and Cape Henlapem bore S.W by W 1/2. A. So ends these 24 hours.
Wind SouthSouthWest Passed the Brandywine shoal at 4 AM. the tide turning Ebb Passed Fort Delaware at noon. Passed Chester Del at 4 PM. Anchored at the mouth of the Scuylkill at 5.30 P.M.
